   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading">Turkey</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="vector-body"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" lang="en" dir="ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the country. For the bird, see <a href="/wiki/Turkey_(bird)" title="Turkey (bird)">Turkey (bird)</a>. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Turkey_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Turkey (disambiguation)">Turkey (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p> 
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country straddling Western Asia and Southeast Europe
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       "Türkiye" redirects here. For the newspaper, see <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrkiye_(newspaper)" title="Türkiye (newspaper)">Türkiye (newspaper)</a>.
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p>

      <p><b>Turkey</b> (<a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>: <i lang="tr">Türkiye</i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Turkish" title="Help:IPA/Turkish">[ˈtyɾcije]</a></span>), officially the <b>Republic of Turkey</b>,<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[a]</a></sup> is a country straddling <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Europe" title="Southeast Europe">Southeast Europe</a>. It shares borders with <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> to the northwest; the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> to the north; <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a> to the northeast; <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a> to the east; <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a> to the southeast; <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> to the south; and the <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea" title="Aegean Sea">Aegean Sea</a> to the west. <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_and_towns_in_Turkey" title="List of largest cities and towns in Turkey">largest city</a>, is the <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">financial centre</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a> is the capital. <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turks</a> form the vast majority of the nation's population, and <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurds</a> are the largest minority.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-4">[4]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>One of the world's earliest permanently settled regions, present-day Turkey was home to important <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> sites like <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="Göbekli Tepe">Göbekli Tepe</a>, and was inhabited by ancient civilisations such as the <a href="/wiki/Hattians" title="Hattians">Hattians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_peoples" title="Anatolian peoples">Anatolian peoples</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Howard2_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard2-12">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon20112_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon20112-13">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MET_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MET-14">[13]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">Hellenization</a> started in the area during the era of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> and continued into the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_era" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine era">Byzantine era</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon20112_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon20112-13">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FreedmanMyers20002_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FreedmanMyers20002-15">[14]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">Seljuk Turks</a> began migrating in the 11th century, and the <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">Sultanate of Rum</a> ruled <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a> until the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Anatolia" title="Mongol invasions of Anatolia">Mongol invasion</a> in 1243, when it disintegrated into small <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_beyliks" title="Anatolian beyliks">Turkish principalities</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-mfk&amp;gl2_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mfk&amp;gl2-16">[15]</a></sup> Beginning in the late 13th century, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_dynasty" title="Ottoman dynasty">Ottomans</a> started <a href="/wiki/Rise_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Rise of the Ottoman Empire">uniting the principalities and conquering the Balkans</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Turkification" title="Turkification">Turkification</a> of Anatolia increased during the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman period</a>. After <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Mehmed II">Mehmed II</a> conquered <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">Constantinople</a> in 1453, Ottoman expansion continued under <a href="/wiki/Selim_I" title="Selim I">Selim I</a>. During the reign of <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">Suleiman the Magnificent</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> became a <a href="/wiki/Transformation_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Transformation of the Ottoman Empire">global power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Howard2_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard2-12">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-masters_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-masters-17">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[17]</a></sup> From the late 18th century onwards, the <a href="/wiki/Decline_and_modernization_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Decline and modernization of the Ottoman Empire">empire's power declined</a> with a gradual loss of territories and wars.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[18]</a></sup> In an effort to consolidate the weakening empire, <a href="/wiki/Mahmud_II" title="Mahmud II">Mahmud II</a> started a <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">period of modernisation</a> in the early 19th century.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[19]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/1913_Ottoman_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1913 Ottoman coup d'état">1913 coup d'état</a> effectively put the country under the control of the <a href="/wiki/Three_Pashas" title="Three Pashas">Three Pashas</a>, who were largely responsible for the Empire's <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_entry_into_World_War_I" title="Ottoman entry into World War I">entry into World War I</a> in 1914. During <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, the Ottoman government committed <a href="/wiki/Late_Ottoman_genocides" title="Late Ottoman genocides">genocides</a> against its <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide" class="mw-redirect" title="Armenian Genocide">Armenian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_genocide" class="mw-redirect" title="Assyrian genocide">Assyrian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">Pontic Greek</a> subjects.<sup id="cite_ref-two_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-two-23">[b]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SchallerZimmerer_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SchallerZimmerer-24">[22]</a></sup> After the Ottomans and the other <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> lost the war, the Ottoman Empire was <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Partition of the Ottoman Empire">partitioned</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[23]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_War_of_Independence" title="Turkish War of Independence">Turkish War of Independence</a> against the occupying <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied Powers</a> resulted in the <a href="/wiki/Abolition_of_the_Ottoman_sultanate" title="Abolition of the Ottoman sultanate">abolition of the Sultanate</a> on 1 November 1922, the signing of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a> (which superseded the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of Sèvres">Treaty of Sèvres</a>) on 24 July 1923 and the proclamation of the Republic on 29 October 1923. With the <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="Atatürk's Reforms">reforms</a> initiated by the country's first president, <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">Mustafa Kemal Atatürk</a>, Turkey became a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular</a>, <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a>; which was later replaced by a <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential system</a> with a <a href="/wiki/2017_Turkish_constitutional_referendum" title="2017 Turkish constitutional referendum">referendum in 2017</a>. Since then, the new Turkish <a href="/wiki/Regime" title="Regime">governmental system</a> under president <a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">Recep Tayyip Erdoğan</a> and his party, the <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Development_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice and Development Party (Turkey)">AKP</a>, has often been described as <a href="/wiki/Right-wing_populism" title="Right-wing populism">populist</a>, <a href="/wiki/Conservatism#Religious_conservatism" title="Conservatism">conservative</a> and <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[28]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Turkey is a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized country</a>, with a geopolitically strategic location.<sup id="cite_ref-giga-hamburg.de1_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-giga-hamburg.de1-31">[29]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Turkey" title="Economy of Turkey">economy</a>, which is classified among the <a href="/wiki/Emerging_and_growth-leading_economies" title="Emerging and growth-leading economies">emerging and growth-leading economies</a>, is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">twentieth-largest in the world</a> by nominal GDP, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">eleventh-largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>. It is a charter member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, an early member of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">IMF</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, and a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_the_Black_Sea_Economic_Cooperation" title="Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation">BSEC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">OIC</a>, and <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>. After becoming <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Council_of_Europe" title="Member states of the Council of Europe">one of the early members</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> in 1950, Turkey became an <a href="/wiki/Ankara_Agreement" title="Ankara Agreement">associate member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">EEC</a> in 1963, joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">EU Customs Union</a> in 1995, and started <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">accession negotiations</a> with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in 2005. </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Turkey" title="Name of Turkey">Name of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The English name of Turkey (from <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Latin" title="Medieval Latin">Medieval Latin</a> <i>Turchia</i>/<i>Turquia</i><sup id="cite_ref-arlen_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arlen-32">[30]</a></sup>) means "land of the Turks". <a href="/wiki/Middle_English" title="Middle English">Middle English</a> usage of <i>Turkye</i> is evidenced in an early work by <a href="/wiki/Chaucer" class="mw-redirect" title="Chaucer">Chaucer</a> called <i><a href="/wiki/The_Book_of_the_Duchess" title="The Book of the Duchess">The Book of the Duchess</a></i> (c. 1369). The phrase <i>land of Torke</i> is used in the 15th-century <a href="/wiki/The_Digby_Conversion_of_Saint_Paul" title="The Digby Conversion of Saint Paul">Digby Mysteries</a>. Later usages can be found in the <a href="/wiki/William_Dunbar" title="William Dunbar">Dunbar poems</a>, the 16th century <i><a href="/wiki/Manipulus_Vocabulorum" title="Manipulus Vocabulorum">Manipulus Vocabulorum</a></i> (<i>Turkie</i>) and <a href="/wiki/Francis_Bacon" title="Francis Bacon">Francis Bacon</a>'s <i>Sylva Sylvarum</i> (<i>Turky</i>). The modern spelling <i>Turkey</i> dates back to at least 1719.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[31]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Turkey" title="History of Turkey">History of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Anatolia" title="History of Anatolia">History of Anatolia</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Thrace" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Thrace">History of Thrace</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_of_Anatolia_and_Eastern_Thrace">Prehistory of Anatolia and Eastern Thrace</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Anatolia" title="Prehistory of Anatolia">Prehistory of Anatolia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Southeastern_Europe" title="Prehistory of Southeastern Europe">Prehistory of Southeastern Europe</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Anatolians" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient Anatolians">Ancient Anatolians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_kingdoms_of_Anatolia" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient kingdoms of Anatolia">Ancient kingdoms of Anatolia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Thracians" title="Thracians">Thracians</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe,_Urfa.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg/220px-G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg/330px-G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg/440px-G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe,_Urfa.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Some <a href="/wiki/Henge" title="Henge">henges</a> at <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="Göbekli Tepe">Göbekli Tepe</a> were erected as far back as <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe#Layer_III" title="Göbekli Tepe">9600 BC</a>, predating those of <a href="/wiki/Stonehenge" title="Stonehenge">Stonehenge</a>, <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a>, by over seven millennia.<sup id="cite_ref-ArchMag_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArchMag-34">[32]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sphinx_Gate,_Hattusa_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Sphinx_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg/220px-Sphinx_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Sphinx_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg/330px-Sphinx_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Sphinx_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg/440px-Sphinx_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sphinx_Gate,_Hattusa_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The Sphinx Gate in <a href="/wiki/Hattusa" title="Hattusa">Hattusa</a> (<a href="/wiki/Hittite_language" title="Hittite language">Hittite</a>: 𒌷𒄩𒀜𒌅𒊭 <i>Ḫattuša</i>), capital of the <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">Hittite Empire</a>. The city's history dates back to the 6th millennium BC.<sup id="cite_ref-whcunesco_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-whcunesco-35">[33]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Anatolian peninsula, comprising most of modern Turkey, is one of the oldest permanently settled regions in the world. Various <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Anatolians" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient Anatolians">ancient Anatolian</a> populations have lived in <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>, from at least the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> until the <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Hellenistic civilization">Hellenistic period</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon20112_13-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon20112-13">[12]</a></sup> Many of these peoples spoke the <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_languages" title="Anatolian languages">Anatolian languages</a>, a branch of the larger <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_language_family" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-European language family">Indo-European language family</a>:<sup id="cite_ref-UCLA_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UCLA-36">[34]</a></sup> and, given the antiquity of the Indo-European <a href="/wiki/Hittite_language" title="Hittite language">Hittite</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luwian_language" title="Luwian language">Luwian</a> languages, some scholars have proposed <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_hypothesis" title="Anatolian hypothesis">Anatolia as the hypothetical centre from which the Indo-European languages radiated</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-AnatoliaIndoEuropean_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AnatoliaIndoEuropean-37">[35]</a></sup> The European part of Turkey, called <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Thrace" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Thrace">Eastern Thrace</a>, has also been inhabited since at least forty thousand years ago, and is known to have been in the Neolithic era by about 6000 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-MET_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MET-14">[13]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="Göbekli Tepe">Göbekli Tepe</a> is the site of the oldest known man-made religious structure, a temple dating to circa 10,000 BC,<sup id="cite_ref-ArchMag_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArchMag-34">[32]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/%C3%87atalh%C3%B6y%C3%BCk" title="Çatalhöyük">Çatalhöyük</a> is a very large Neolithic and <a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">Chalcolithic</a> settlement in southern Anatolia, which existed from approximately 7500 BC to 5700 BC. It is the largest and best-preserved Neolithic site found to date and is a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[36]</a></sup> The settlement of <a href="/wiki/Troy" title="Troy">Troy</a> started in the Neolithic Age and continued into the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[37]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The earliest recorded inhabitants of Anatolia were the <a href="/wiki/Hattians" title="Hattians">Hattians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hurrians" title="Hurrians">Hurrians</a>, non-Indo-European peoples who inhabited central and eastern Anatolia, respectively, as early as c. 2300 BC. Indo-European <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">Hittites</a> came to Anatolia and gradually absorbed the Hattians and Hurrians c. 2000–1700 BC. The first major empire in the area was founded by the Hittites, from the 18th through the 13th century BC. The <a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">Assyrians</a> conquered and settled parts of southeastern Turkey as early as 1950 BC until the year 612 BC,<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[38]</a></sup> although they <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_continuity" title="Assyrian continuity">have remained a minority</a> in the region, namely in <a href="/wiki/Hakkari" title="Hakkari">Hakkari</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%9E%C4%B1rnak_Province" title="Şırnak Province">Şırnak</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mardin_province" class="mw-redirect" title="Mardin province">Mardin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[39]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Urartu" title="Urartu">Urartu</a> re-emerged in Assyrian inscriptions in the 9th century BC as a powerful northern rival of Assyria.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[40]</a></sup> Following the collapse of the Hittite empire c. 1180 BC, the <a href="/wiki/Phrygia" title="Phrygia">Phrygians</a>, an Indo-European people, achieved ascendancy in Anatolia until their kingdom was destroyed by the <a href="/wiki/Cimmerians" title="Cimmerians">Cimmerians</a> in the 7th century BC.<sup id="cite_ref-TroyHittiteEmpirePhrygians_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TroyHittiteEmpirePhrygians-43">[41]</a></sup> Starting from 714 BC, Urartu shared the same fate and dissolved in 590 BC,<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[42]</a></sup> when it was conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Medes</a>. The most powerful of Phrygia's successor states were <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">Lydia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caria" title="Caria">Caria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lycia" title="Lycia">Lycia</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Antiquity">Antiquity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Classical_Anatolia" title="Classical Anatolia">Classical Anatolia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_period" title="Hellenistic period">Hellenistic period</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_theatre_of_ancient_Halicarnassus,_built_in_the_4th_century_BC_during_the_reign_of_King_Mausolos_and_enlarged_in_the_2nd_century_AD,_the_original_capacity_of_the_theatre_was_10,000,_Bodrum,_Turkey_(16456817694).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/The_theatre_of_ancient_Halicarnassus%2C_built_in_the_4th_century_BC_during_the_reign_of_King_Mausolos_and_enlarged_in_the_2nd_century_AD%2C_the_original_capacity_of_the_theatre_was_10%2C000%2C_Bodrum%2C_Turkey_%2816456817694%29.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/The_theatre_of_ancient_Halicarnassus%2C_built_in_the_4th_century_BC_during_the_reign_of_King_Mausolos_and_enlarged_in_the_2nd_century_AD%2C_the_original_capacity_of_the_theatre_was_10%2C000%2C_Bodrum%2C_Turkey_%2816456817694%29.jpg/330px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/The_theatre_of_ancient_Halicarnassus%2C_built_in_the_4th_century_BC_during_the_reign_of_King_Mausolos_and_enlarged_in_the_2nd_century_AD%2C_the_original_capacity_of_the_theatre_was_10%2C000%2C_Bodrum%2C_Turkey_%2816456817694%29.jpg/440px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4817" data-file-height="3190"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_theatre_of_ancient_Halicarnassus,_built_in_the_4th_century_BC_during_the_reign_of_King_Mausolos_and_enlarged_in_the_2nd_century_AD,_the_original_capacity_of_the_theatre_was_10,000,_Bodrum,_Turkey_(16456817694).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Theatre_at_Halicarnassus" title="Theatre at Halicarnassus">Theatre at Halicarnassus</a> (modern <a href="/wiki/Bodrum" title="Bodrum">Bodrum</a>) was built in the 4th century BC by <a href="/wiki/Mausolus" title="Mausolus">Mausolus</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Persian</a> <a href="/wiki/Satrap" title="Satrap">satrap</a> (governor) of <a href="/wiki/Caria#Persian_satrapy" title="Caria">Caria</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Mausoleum_at_Halicarnassus" title="Mausoleum at Halicarnassus">Mausoleum at Halicarnassus</a> was one of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World" title="Seven Wonders of the Ancient World">Seven Wonders of the Ancient World</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[43]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/220px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/330px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/440px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg 2x" data-file-width="9163" data-file-height="7100"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Celsus" title="Library of Celsus">Library of Celsus</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">Ephesus</a> was built by the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Romans</a> in 114–117.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[44]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Artemis" title="Temple of Artemis">Temple of Artemis</a> in Ephesus, built by king <a href="/wiki/Croesus" title="Croesus">Croesus</a> of <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">Lydia</a> in the 6th century BC, was one of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World" title="Seven Wonders of the Ancient World">Seven Wonders of the Ancient World</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[45]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Starting around 1200 BC, the coast of Anatolia was heavily settled by <a href="/wiki/Aeolians" title="Aeolians">Aeolian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ionians" title="Ionians">Ionian</a> <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greeks</a>. Numerous important <a href="/wiki/Polis" title="Polis">cities</a> were founded by these colonists, such as <a href="/wiki/Miletus" title="Miletus">Miletus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">Ephesus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Smyrna" title="Smyrna">Smyrna</a> (now <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0zmir" title="İzmir">İzmir</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">Byzantium</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>), the latter founded by <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greek</a> colonists from <a href="/wiki/Megara" title="Megara">Megara</a> in 657 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[46]</a></sup> The first state that was called <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a> by neighbouring peoples was the state of the <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">Armenian</a> <a href="/wiki/Orontid_dynasty" title="Orontid dynasty">Orontid dynasty</a>, which included parts of eastern Turkey beginning in the 6th century BC. In Northwest Turkey, the most significant tribal group in Thrace was the <a href="/wiki/Odrysian_kingdom" title="Odrysian kingdom">Odyrisians</a>, founded by <a href="/wiki/Teres_I" title="Teres I">Teres I</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-LewisBoardman1994_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LewisBoardman1994-49">[47]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>All of modern-day Turkey was conquered by the Persian <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a> during the 6th century BC.<sup id="cite_ref-A_companion_to_Ancient_Macedonia_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A_companion_to_Ancient_Macedonia-50">[48]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Greco-Persian_Wars" title="Greco-Persian Wars">Greco-Persian Wars</a> started when the Greek city states on the coast of Anatolia rebelled against Persian rule in 499 BC. The territory of Turkey later fell to <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> in 334 BC,<sup id="cite_ref-PersiansInAsiaMinor_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PersiansInAsiaMinor-51">[49]</a></sup> which led to increasing cultural homogeneity and <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">Hellenization</a> in the area.<sup id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon20112_13-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon20112-13">[12]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Following Alexander's death in 323 BC, Anatolia was subsequently divided into a number of small Hellenistic kingdoms, all of which became part of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a> by the mid-1st century BC.<sup id="cite_ref-AlexanderToRome_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AlexanderToRome-52">[50]</a></sup> The process of Hellenization that began with Alexander's conquest accelerated under Roman rule, and by the early centuries of the <a href="/wiki/Christian_Era" class="mw-redirect" title="Christian Era">Christian Era</a>, the local Anatolian languages and cultures had become extinct, being largely replaced by <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient Greek language">ancient Greek language</a> and culture.<sup id="cite_ref-FreedmanMyers20002_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FreedmanMyers20002-15">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hout2011_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hout2011-53">[51]</a></sup> From the 1st century BC up to the 3rd century CE, large parts of modern-day Turkey were contested between the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Romans</a> and neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthians</a> through the frequent <a href="/wiki/Roman-Parthian_Wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman-Parthian Wars">Roman-Parthian Wars</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Christian_and_Byzantine_period">Early Christian and Byzantine period</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Early_Christianity" class="mw-redirect" title="Early Christianity">Early Christianity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Anatolia" title="Byzantine Anatolia">Byzantine Anatolia</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Successors_of_the_Byzantine_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Successors of the Byzantine Empire">Successors of the Byzantine Empire</a> and <a href="/wiki/States_in_late_medieval_Anatolia" class="mw-redirect" title="States in late medieval Anatolia">States in late medieval Anatolia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_(2216460729).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg/220px-Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg/330px-Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg/440px-Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3329" data-file-height="2534"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_(2216460729).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Originally a church, then a mosque, later a museum, and now a mosque again, the <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Sophia" title="Hagia Sophia">Hagia Sophia</a> in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> was built by the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine</a> emperor <a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">Justinian I</a> in 532–537 AD.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[52]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Apostles" class="mw-redirect" title="Acts of Apostles">Acts of Apostles</a> 11,<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[53]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Antioch" title="Antioch">Antioch</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Antakya" title="Antakya">Antakya</a>), a city in southern Turkey, is the birthplace of the <a href="/wiki/Early_Christianity" class="mw-redirect" title="Early Christianity">first Christian community</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[54]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 324, <a href="/wiki/Constantine_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Constantine I">Constantine I</a> chose Byzantium to be the new capital of the Roman Empire, renaming it <a href="/wiki/New_Rome" title="New Rome">New Rome</a>. Following the death of <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_I" title="Theodosius I">Theodosius I</a> in 395 and the permanent division of the Roman Empire between his two sons, the city, which would popularly come to be known as <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>, became the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Roman Empire">Eastern Roman Empire</a>. This empire, which would later be branded by historians as the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>, ruled most of the territory of present-day Turkey until the <a href="/wiki/Late_Middle_Ages" title="Late Middle Ages">Late Middle Ages</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[55]</a></sup> although the eastern regions remained firmly in <a href="/wiki/Sasanian" class="mw-redirect" title="Sasanian">Sasanian</a> hands up to the first half of the seventh century. The frequent <a href="/wiki/Byzantine-Sassanid_Wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine-Sassanid Wars">Byzantine-Sassanid Wars</a>, as part of the centuries long-lasting <a href="/wiki/Roman-Persian_Wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman-Persian Wars">Roman-Persian Wars</a>, fought between the neighbouring rivalling Byzantines and Sasanians, took place in various parts of present-day Turkey and decided much of the latter's<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="not clear what &quot;the latter&quot; is referring to (March 2020)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> history from the fourth century up to the first half of the seventh century. </p>
      <p>Several <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_councils" class="mw-redirect" title="Ecumenical councils">ecumenical councils</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Early_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Early Church">early Church</a> were held in cities located in present-day Turkey including the <a href="/wiki/First_Council_of_Nicaea" title="First Council of Nicaea">First Council of Nicaea</a> (<a href="/wiki/Iznik" class="mw-redirect" title="Iznik">Iznik</a>) in 325, the <a href="/wiki/First_Council_of_Constantinople" title="First Council of Constantinople">First Council of Constantinople</a> (Istanbul) in 381, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ephesus" title="Council of Ephesus">Council of Ephesus</a> in 431, and the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon" title="Council of Chalcedon">Council of Chalcedon</a> (<a href="/wiki/Kad%C4%B1k%C3%B6y" title="Kadıköy">Kadıköy</a>) in 451.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[56]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Seljuks_and_the_Ottoman_Empire">Seljuks and the Ottoman Empire</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_dynasty" title="Seljuk dynasty">Seljuk dynasty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_dynasty" title="Ottoman dynasty">Ottoman dynasty</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Turkic_migration" title="Turkic migration">Turkic migration</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Anatolia" title="Mongol invasions of Anatolia">Mongol invasions of Anatolia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">Seljuk Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">Sultanate of Rum</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Seljuq_dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Seljuq dynasty">House of Seljuk</a> originated from the <i><a href="/wiki/K%C4%B1n%C4%B1k_(tribe)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kınık (tribe)">Kınık</a></i> branch of the <a href="/wiki/Oghuz_Turks" title="Oghuz Turks">Oghuz Turks</a> who resided on the periphery of the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_history#Abbasids_-_&quot;Islamic_Golden_Age&quot;" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim history">Muslim world</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Oghuz_Yabgu_State" title="Oghuz Yabgu State">Yabgu Khaganate</a> of the Oğuz confederacy, to the north of the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aral_Sea" title="Aral Sea">Aral Seas</a>, in the 9th century.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[57]</a></sup> In the 10th century, the Seljuks started migrating from their ancestral homeland into <a href="/wiki/Persia" class="mw-redirect" title="Persia">Persia</a>, which became the administrative core of the <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">Great Seljuk Empire</a>, after its foundation by <a href="/wiki/Tughril" title="Tughril">Tughril</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-peter.mackenzie.org_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-peter.mackenzie.org-60">[58]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the latter half of the 11th century, the Seljuk Turks began penetrating into <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Armenia" title="Medieval Armenia">medieval Armenia</a> and the eastern regions of Anatolia. In 1071, the Seljuks defeated the Byzantines at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Manzikert" title="Battle of Manzikert">Battle of Manzikert</a>, starting the <a href="/wiki/Turkification" title="Turkification">Turkification</a> process in the area; the Turkish language and <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> were introduced to Armenia and Anatolia, gradually spreading throughout the region. The slow transition from a predominantly <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>-speaking Anatolia to a predominantly <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> and Turkish-speaking one was underway. The <a href="/wiki/Mevlevi_Order" title="Mevlevi Order">Mevlevi Order</a> of <a href="/wiki/Dervishes" class="mw-redirect" title="Dervishes">dervishes</a>, which was established in <a href="/wiki/Konya" title="Konya">Konya</a> during the 13th century by <a href="/wiki/Sufi" class="mw-redirect" title="Sufi">Sufi</a> poet <a href="/wiki/Celaleddin_Rumi" class="mw-redirect" title="Celaleddin Rumi">Celaleddin Rumi</a>, played a significant role in the <a href="/wiki/Islamization" title="Islamization">Islamization</a> of the diverse people of Anatolia who had previously been <a href="/wiki/Hellenized" class="mw-redirect" title="Hellenized">Hellenized</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[60]</a></sup> Thus, alongside the Turkification of the territory, the <a href="/wiki/Persianate_society" title="Persianate society">culturally Persianized</a> Seljuks set the basis for a <a href="/wiki/Turko-Persian_tradition" class="mw-redirect" title="Turko-Persian tradition">Turko-Persian principal culture</a> in Anatolia,<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[61]</a></sup> which their eventual successors, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Culture of the Ottoman Empire">the Ottomans</a>, would take over.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[63]</a></sup> </p> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/200px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="100" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/300px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/400px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3635" data-file-height="1817"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Dolmabahce_Palacemm.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Dolmabahce_Palacemm.jpg/200px-Dolmabahce_Palacemm.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Dolmabahce_Palacemm.jpg/300px-Dolmabahce_Palacemm.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Dolmabahce_Palacemm.jpg/400px-Dolmabahce_Palacemm.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3008" data-file-height="2000"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace" title="Topkapı Palace">Topkapı</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="Dolmabahçe Palace">Dolmabahçe</a> palaces were the primary residences of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_sultans_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="List of sultans of the Ottoman Empire">Sultans</a> in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> between 1465 to 1856<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-66">[64]</a></sup> and 1856 to 1922,<sup id="cite_ref-dolmabahcepalace_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dolmabahcepalace-67">[65]</a></sup> respectively.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1243, the Seljuk armies were defeated by the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_Empire" title="Mongol Empire">Mongols</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_K%C3%B6se_Da%C4%9F" title="Battle of Köse Dağ">Battle of Köse Dağ</a>, causing the Seljuk Empire's power to slowly disintegrate. In its wake, one of the <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_beyliks" title="Anatolian beyliks">Turkish principalities</a> governed by <a href="/wiki/Osman_I" title="Osman I">Osman I</a> would evolve over the next 200 years into the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. The Ottomans completed their conquest of the Byzantine Empire by <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">capturing its capital, Constantinople</a>, in 1453: their commander thenceforth being known as <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_the_Conqueror" title="Mehmed the Conqueror">Mehmed the Conqueror</a>. </p>
      <p>In 1514, Sultan <a href="/wiki/Selim_I" title="Selim I">Selim I</a> (1512–1520) successfully expanded the empire's southern and eastern borders by defeating Shah <a href="/wiki/Ismail_I" title="Ismail I">Ismail I</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Safavid_dynasty" title="Safavid dynasty">Safavid dynasty</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Chaldiran" title="Battle of Chaldiran">Battle of Chaldiran</a>. In 1517, Selim I expanded Ottoman rule into <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Algeria" title="Ottoman Algeria">Algeria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Mamluk_War_(1516%E2%80%931517)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman–Mamluk War (1516–1517)">Egypt</a>, and created a naval presence in the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a>. Subsequently, a contest started between the Ottoman and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> empires to become the dominant sea power in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_naval_expeditions_in_the_Indian_Ocean" title="Ottoman naval expeditions in the Indian Ocean">a number of naval battles</a> in the Red Sea, the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a>. The Portuguese presence in the Indian Ocean was perceived as a threat to the Ottoman monopoly over the <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">ancient trade routes</a> between <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a>. Despite the increasingly prominent European presence, the Ottoman Empire's trade with the east continued to flourish until the second half of the 18th century.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[66]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Ottoman Empire's power and prestige peaked in the 16th and 17th centuries, particularly during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">Suleiman the Magnificent</a>, who personally instituted major legislative changes relating to society, education, taxation and criminal law. </p>
      <p>The empire was often at odds with the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a> in its steady advance towards <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a> through the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a> and the southern part of the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-69">[67]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:OttomanEmpireMain.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/OttomanEmpireMain.png/220px-OttomanEmpireMain.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="158" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/OttomanEmpireMain.png/330px-OttomanEmpireMain.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/OttomanEmpireMain.png/440px-OttomanEmpireMain.png 2x" data-file-width="3597" data-file-height="2581"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:OttomanEmpireMain.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vienna" title="Battle of Vienna">Second Ottoman Siege of Vienna</a> in 1683 (the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Vienna_(1529)" title="Siege of Vienna (1529)">First Siege</a> was in 1529) initiated the <a href="/wiki/Great_Turkish_War" title="Great Turkish War">Great Turkish War</a> (1683–1699) between the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottomans</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1684)" title="Holy League (1684)">Holy League</a> of European states.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Navy" title="Ottoman Navy">Ottoman Navy</a> contended with several Holy Leagues, such as those in <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1538)" title="Holy League (1538)">1538</a>, <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1571)" title="Holy League (1571)">1571</a>, <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1684)" title="Holy League (1684)">1684</a> and <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1717)" title="Holy League (1717)">1717</a> (composed primarily of <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Spain" title="Habsburg Spain">Habsburg Spain</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa" title="Republic of Genoa">Republic of Genoa</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">Republic of Venice</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller" title="Knights Hospitaller">Knights of St. John</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Tuscany" title="Grand Duchy of Tuscany">Grand Duchy of Tuscany</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Savoy" title="Duchy of Savoy">Duchy of Savoy</a>), for the control of the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>. </p>
      <p>In the east, the Ottomans were often at war with Safavid Persia over conflicts stemming from territorial disputes or religious differences between the 16th and 18th centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[68]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ottoman-Persian_Wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman-Persian Wars">Ottoman wars with Persia</a> continued as the <a href="/wiki/Zand_dynasty" title="Zand dynasty">Zand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afsharid_dynasty" title="Afsharid dynasty">Afsharid</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Qajar_dynasty" title="Qajar dynasty">Qajar</a> dynasties succeeded the Safavids in Iran, until the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Persian_War_(1821%E2%80%931823)" title="Ottoman–Persian War (1821–1823)">first half of the 19th century</a>. </p>
      <p>Even further east, there was an extension of the Habsburg-Ottoman conflict, in that the Ottomans also had to <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_expedition_to_Aceh" title="Ottoman expedition to Aceh">send soldiers</a> to their farthest and easternmost vassal and territory, the <a href="/wiki/Aceh_Sultanate" title="Aceh Sultanate">Aceh Sultanate</a><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[70]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, to defend it from European colonizers as well as the <a href="/wiki/Juan_de_Salcedo" title="Juan de Salcedo">Latino invaders</a> who had crossed from <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> and had Christianized the formerly Muslim-dominated <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_the_Philippines" title="Islam in the Philippines">Philippines</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[71]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>From the 16th to the early 20th centuries, the Ottoman Empire also <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_Wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Russo-Turkish Wars">fought twelve wars</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Russian Tsardom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Empire</a>. These were initially about Ottoman territorial expansion and consolidation in southeastern and eastern Europe; but starting from the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1768%E2%80%931774)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1768–1774)">Russo-Turkish War (1768–1774)</a>, they became more about the survival of the Ottoman Empire, which had begun to lose its strategic territories on the northern <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> coast to the advancing Russians. </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:358px;max-width:358px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:102px;max-width:102px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Selimiye_Mosque_(15051985908)_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Selimiye_Mosque_%2815051985908%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/100px-Selimiye_Mosque_%2815051985908%29_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="100" height="127" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Selimiye_Mosque_%2815051985908%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/150px-Selimiye_Mosque_%2815051985908%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Selimiye_Mosque_%2815051985908%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/200px-Selimiye_Mosque_%2815051985908%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3931" data-file-height="4990"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Blue_Mosque_(The_Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque)_(8396648956)_cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Blue_Mosque_%28The_Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque%29_%288396648956%29_cropped.jpg/250px-Blue_Mosque_%28The_Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque%29_%288396648956%29_cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="127" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Blue_Mosque_%28The_Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque%29_%288396648956%29_cropped.jpg/375px-Blue_Mosque_%28The_Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque%29_%288396648956%29_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Blue_Mosque_%28The_Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque%29_%288396648956%29_cropped.jpg/500px-Blue_Mosque_%28The_Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque%29_%288396648956%29_cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2184"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          The <a href="/wiki/Selimiye_Mosque,_Edirne" title="Selimiye Mosque, Edirne">Selimiye Mosque</a> in <a href="/wiki/Edirne" title="Edirne">Edirne</a> (left, 1568–1575, designed by <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Sinan" title="Mimar Sinan">Mimar Sinan</a>) and the <a href="/wiki/Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque" title="Sultan Ahmed Mosque">Sultan Ahmed Mosque</a> in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> (right, 1609–1616, designed by <a href="/wiki/Sedefkar_Mehmed_Agha" title="Sedefkar Mehmed Agha">Sedefkâr Mehmed Ağa</a>) are among the renowned examples of <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">Ottoman architecture</a>.
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>From the second half of the 18th century onwards, the <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Decline of the Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire began to decline</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Tanzimat</a> reforms, initiated by <a href="/wiki/Mahmud_II" title="Mahmud II">Mahmud II</a> just before his death in 1839, aimed to modernise the Ottoman state in line with the progress that had been made in Western Europe. The efforts of <a href="/wiki/Midhat_Pasha" title="Midhat Pasha">Midhat Pasha</a> during the late Tanzimat era led the Ottoman <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_constitution_of_1876" title="Ottoman constitution of 1876">constitutional movement of 1876</a>, which introduced the <a href="/wiki/First_Constitutional_Era" title="First Constitutional Era">First Constitutional Era</a>, but these efforts proved to be inadequate in most fields, and failed to stop the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Dissolution of the Ottoman Empire">dissolution of the empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-OttoTurkVis_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OttoTurkVis-74">[72]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As the empire gradually shrank in size, military power and wealth; especially after the <a href="/wiki/Great_Eastern_Crisis" title="Great Eastern Crisis">Ottoman economic crisis and default</a> in 1875<sup id="cite_ref-NiallFergusonFT_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NiallFergusonFT-75">[73]</a></sup> which led to uprisings in the Balkan provinces that culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1877%E2%80%931878)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)">Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)</a>; many Balkan Muslims migrated to the Empire's heartland in Anatolia,<sup id="cite_ref-Illinois2009_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Illinois2009-76">[74]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[75]</a></sup> along with the <a href="/wiki/Circassians" title="Circassians">Circassians</a> fleeing the <a href="/wiki/Russian%E2%80%93Circassian_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian–Circassian War">Russian conquest</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_conquest_of_the_Caucasus" title="Russian conquest of the Caucasus">Caucasus</a>. The decline of the Ottoman Empire led to a <a href="/wiki/Rise_of_nationalism_under_the_Ottoman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Rise of nationalism under the Ottoman Empire">rise in nationalist sentiment among its various subject peoples</a>, leading to increased ethnic tensions which occasionally burst into violence, such as the <a href="/wiki/Hamidian_massacres" title="Hamidian massacres">Hamidian massacres</a> of Armenians.<sup id="cite_ref-nzhistory.net.nz_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nzhistory.net.nz-78">[76]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Wilhelm_II_-_V.Mehmet_Re%C5%9Fat_-_Enver_Pasha.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Wilhelm_II_-_V.Mehmet_Re%C5%9Fat_-_Enver_Pasha.jpg/220px-Wilhelm_II_-_V.Mehmet_Re%C5%9Fat_-_Enver_Pasha.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="143" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Wilhelm_II_-_V.Mehmet_Re%C5%9Fat_-_Enver_Pasha.jpg/330px-Wilhelm_II_-_V.Mehmet_Re%C5%9Fat_-_Enver_Pasha.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Wilhelm_II_-_V.Mehmet_Re%C5%9Fat_-_Enver_Pasha.jpg/440px-Wilhelm_II_-_V.Mehmet_Re%C5%9Fat_-_Enver_Pasha.jpg 2x" data-file-width="577" data-file-height="376"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Wilhelm_II_-_V.Mehmet_Re%C5%9Fat_-_Enver_Pasha.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_II,_German_Emperor" title="Wilhelm II, German Emperor">Kaiser Wilhelm II</a> with <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_V" title="Mehmed V">Sultan Mehmed V</a> and <a href="/wiki/Enver_Pasha" title="Enver Pasha">Enver Pasha</a> in <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> (<a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>), 1917. The Ottomans joined <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> on the side of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-britishcouncil.org1_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britishcouncil.org1-79">[77]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The loss of <a href="/wiki/Rumelia" title="Rumelia">Rumelia</a> (Ottoman territories in Europe) with the <a href="/wiki/First_Balkan_War" title="First Balkan War">First Balkan War</a> (1912–1913) was followed by the arrival of millions of Muslim refugees (<i><a href="/wiki/Muhacir" title="Muhacir">muhacir</a></i>) to Istanbul and Anatolia.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[78]</a></sup> Historically, the <a href="/wiki/Rumelia_Eyalet" title="Rumelia Eyalet">Rumelia Eyalet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anatolia_Eyalet" title="Anatolia Eyalet">Anatolia Eyalet</a> had formed the <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Administrative divisions of the Ottoman Empire">administrative</a> core of the Ottoman Empire, with their governors titled <a href="/wiki/Beylerbey" title="Beylerbey">Beylerbeyi</a> participating in the Sultan's <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Council_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Imperial Council (Ottoman Empire)">Divan</a>, so the loss of all Balkan provinces beyond the <a href="/wiki/K%C4%B1y%C4%B1k%C3%B6y" title="Kıyıköy">Midye</a>-<a href="/wiki/Enez" title="Enez">Enez</a> border line according to the <a href="/wiki/London_Conference_of_1912%E2%80%9313" class="mw-redirect" title="London Conference of 1912–13">London Conference of 1912–13</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1913)" title="Treaty of London (1913)">Treaty of London (1913)</a> was a major shock for the Ottoman society and led to the <a href="/wiki/1913_Ottoman_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1913 Ottoman coup d'état">1913 Ottoman coup d'état</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/Second_Balkan_War" title="Second Balkan War">Second Balkan War</a> (1913) the Ottomans managed to recover their former capital <a href="/wiki/Edirne" title="Edirne">Edirne</a> (Adrianople) and its surrounding areas in <a href="/wiki/East_Thrace" title="East Thrace">East Thrace</a>, which was formalised with the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Constantinople_(1913)" title="Treaty of Constantinople (1913)">Treaty of Constantinople (1913)</a>. The 1913 coup d'état effectively put the country under the control of the <a href="/wiki/Three_Pashas" title="Three Pashas">Three Pashas</a>, making sultans <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_V" title="Mehmed V">Mehmed V</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_VI" title="Mehmed VI">Mehmed VI</a> largely symbolic figureheads with no real political power. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Marcharmenians.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Marcharmenians.jpg/220px-Marcharmenians.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="141" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Marcharmenians.jpg/330px-Marcharmenians.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Marcharmenians.jpg/440px-Marcharmenians.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1278"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Marcharmenians.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Armenian civilians being deported during the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide" class="mw-redirect" title="Armenian Genocide">Armenian Genocide</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Ottoman Empire entered <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> on the side of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> and was ultimately defeated. The Ottomans successfully defended the <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">Dardanelles</a> strait during the <a href="/wiki/Gallipoli_campaign" title="Gallipoli campaign">Gallipoli campaign</a> (1915–1916) and achieved initial victories against British forces in the first two years of the <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamian_campaign" title="Mesopotamian campaign">Mesopotamian campaign</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Kut" title="Siege of Kut">Siege of Kut</a> (1915–1916); but the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Revolt" title="Arab Revolt">Arab Revolt</a> (1916–1918) turned the tide against the Ottomans in the Middle East. In the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus_campaign" title="Caucasus campaign">Caucasus campaign</a>, however, the Russian forces had the upper hand from the beginning, especially after the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Sarikamish" title="Battle of Sarikamish">Battle of Sarikamish</a> (1914–1915). Russian forces advanced into northeastern Anatolia and controlled the major cities there until retreating from World War I with the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk" title="Treaty of Brest-Litovsk">Treaty of Brest-Litovsk</a> following the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a> (1917). During the war, the empire's Armenians were <a href="/wiki/Tehcir_Law" title="Tehcir Law">deported</a> to <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a> as part of the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide" class="mw-redirect" title="Armenian Genocide">Armenian Genocide</a>. As a result, an estimated 800,000 to 1,500,000 Armenians were killed.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[79]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[81]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[82]</a></sup> The Turkish government has <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide_denial" class="mw-redirect" title="Armenian Genocide denial">refused to acknowledge</a> the events as <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">genocide</a> and states that Armenians were only <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer" title="Population transfer">relocated</a> from the eastern war zone.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[83]</a></sup> Genocidal campaigns were also committed against the empire's other minority groups such as the <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_genocide" class="mw-redirect" title="Assyrian genocide">Assyrians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">Greeks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bloxham2005_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bloxham2005-86">[84]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Levene_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Levene-87">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ferguson_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ferguson-88">[86]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Mudros" title="Armistice of Mudros">Armistice of Mudros</a> on 30 October 1918, the victorious <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied Powers</a> sought to <a href="/wiki/Partitioning_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Partitioning of the Ottoman Empire">partition the Ottoman state</a> through the 1920 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of Sèvres">Treaty of Sèvres</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Treaty_of_Sèvres_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Treaty_of_Sèvres-89">[87]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Republic_of_Turkey">Republic of Turkey</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="History of the Republic of Turkey">History of the Republic of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="Atatürk's Reforms">Atatürk's Reforms</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg/220px-Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="152" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg/330px-Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg/440px-Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg 2x" data-file-width="780" data-file-height="540"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">Mustafa Kemal Atatürk</a>, founder and first President of the Turkish Republic, with the <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Republican_Party_(Turkey)" title="Liberal Republican Party (Turkey)">Liberal Republican Party</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Fethi_Okyar" title="Fethi Okyar">Fethi Okyar</a> (right) and Okyar's daughter in <a href="/wiki/Yalova" title="Yalova">Yalova</a>, 13 August 1930.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Constantinople" title="Occupation of Constantinople">occupation of Istanbul</a> (1918) and <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Smyrna" title="Occupation of Smyrna">İzmir</a> (1919) by the Allies in the aftermath of World War I prompted the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_National_Movement" title="Turkish National Movement">Turkish National Movement</a>. Under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">Mustafa Kemal</a> <a href="/wiki/Pasha" title="Pasha">Pasha</a>, a military commander who had distinguished himself during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gallipoli" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Gallipoli">Battle of Gallipoli</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_War_of_Independence" title="Turkish War of Independence">Turkish War of Independence</a> (1919–1923) was waged with the aim of revoking the terms of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of Sèvres">Treaty of Sèvres</a> (1920).<sup id="cite_ref-Atatürk_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atatürk-90">[88]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By 18 September 1922 the Greek, Armenian and French armies had been expelled,<sup id="cite_ref-18sep1922_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18sep1922-91">[89]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Provisional_Government" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Provisional Government">Turkish Provisional Government</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a>, which had declared itself the legitimate government of the country on <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">23 April 1920</a>, started to formalise the legal transition from the old Ottoman into the new Republican political system. On 1 November 1922, the Turkish Parliament in Ankara formally <a href="/wiki/Abolition_of_the_Ottoman_Sultanate" class="mw-redirect" title="Abolition of the Ottoman Sultanate">abolished the Sultanate</a>, thus ending 623 years of monarchical Ottoman rule. The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a> of 24 July 1923, which superseded the Treaty of Sèvres,<sup id="cite_ref-Treaty_of_Sèvres_89-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Treaty_of_Sèvres-89">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Atatürk_90-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atatürk-90">[88]</a></sup> led to the international recognition of the sovereignty of the newly formed "Republic of Turkey" as the successor state of the Ottoman Empire, and the republic was officially proclaimed on 29 October 1923 in Ankara, the country's new capital.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[90]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Convention_Concerning_the_Exchange_of_Greek_and_Turkish_Populations" title="Convention Concerning the Exchange of Greek and Turkish Populations">Lausanne Convention</a> stipulated a <a href="/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_and_Turkey" title="Population exchange between Greece and Turkey">population exchange between Greece and Turkey</a>, whereby 1.1&nbsp;million Greeks left Turkey for Greece in exchange for 380,000 Muslims transferred from Greece to Turkey.<sup id="cite_ref-Clogg_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Clogg-93">[91]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_(1935).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg/220px-First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="168" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg/330px-First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg/440px-First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1067" data-file-height="815"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_(1935).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Eighteen female <a href="/wiki/Member_of_parliament" title="Member of parliament">deputies</a> joined the <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">Turkish Parliament</a> with the <a href="/wiki/1935_Turkish_general_election" title="1935 Turkish general election">1935 general elections</a>. Turkish women gained the <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_women%27s_suffrage" title="Timeline of women's suffrage">right to vote and to hold elected office</a> as a mark of the far-reaching <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="Atatürk's Reforms">social changes</a> initiated by <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">Atatürk</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[92]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Mustafa Kemal became the republic's first <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">President</a> and subsequently introduced <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="Atatürk's Reforms">many reforms</a>. The reforms aimed to transform the old <a href="/wiki/Millet_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Millet (Ottoman Empire)">religion-based and multi-communal</a> Ottoman <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> into a Turkish <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a> that would be governed as a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a> under a <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution_of_1924" title="Turkish Constitution of 1924">secular constitution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BoweringCrone2012_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoweringCrone2012-95">[93]</a></sup> With the <a href="/wiki/Surname_Law" class="mw-redirect" title="Surname Law">Surname Law</a> of 1934, the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Parliament">Turkish Parliament</a> bestowed upon Mustafa Kemal the honorific surname "Atatürk" (<i>Father Turk</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-Atatürk_90-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atatürk-90">[88]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Montreux_Convention_Regarding_the_Regime_of_the_Straits" title="Montreux Convention Regarding the Regime of the Straits">Montreux Convention</a> (1936) restored Turkey's control over the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Straits" title="Turkish Straits">Turkish Straits</a>, including the right to militarise the coastlines of the <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">Dardanelles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bosporus" title="Bosporus">Bosporus</a> straits and the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Marmara" title="Sea of Marmara">Sea of Marmara</a>, and to block maritime traffic in wartime.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[94]</a></sup> </p>
