      <p>Following the establishment of the Republic of Turkey in 1923, some <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurdish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zazas" title="Zazas">Zaza</a> tribes, which were <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudal</a> (<a href="/wiki/Manorialism" title="Manorialism">manorial</a>) communities led by <a href="/wiki/Tribal_chief" title="Tribal chief">chieftains</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Agha_(title)" title="Agha (title)">agha</a></i>) during the Ottoman period, became discontent about certain aspects of <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="Atatürk's Reforms">Atatürk's reforms</a> aiming to modernise the country, such as <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secularism</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Said_rebellion" title="Sheikh Said rebellion">Sheikh Said rebellion</a>, 1925)<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[95]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Land_reform" title="Land reform">land reform</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Dersim_rebellion" title="Dersim rebellion">Dersim rebellion</a>, 1937–1938),<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[96]</a></sup> and staged armed revolts that were put down with military operations. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/%C4%B0smet_%C4%B0n%C3%B6n%C3%BC" title="İsmet İnönü">İsmet İnönü</a> became Turkey's second President following Atatürk's death on 10 November 1938. On 29 June 1939, the <a href="/wiki/Hatay_State" title="Hatay State">Republic of Hatay</a> voted in favour of joining Turkey with a referendum. Turkey <a href="/wiki/Second_Cairo_Conference" title="Second Cairo Conference">remained neutral</a> during most of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, but entered the closing stages of the war on the side of the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a> on 23 February 1945. On 26 June 1945, Turkey became a <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Charter" class="mw-redirect" title="United Nations Charter">charter member</a> of the United Nations.<sup id="cite_ref-Turkey_UN_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Turkey_UN-99">[97]</a></sup> In the following year, the <a href="/wiki/One-party_period_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="One-party period of the Republic of Turkey">single-party period</a> in Turkey came to an end, with the <a href="/wiki/1946_Turkish_general_election" title="1946 Turkish general election">first multiparty elections in 1946</a>. In 1950 Turkey became a member of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg/220px-Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg/330px-Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg/440px-Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1512" data-file-height="1209"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Roosevelt</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0smet_%C4%B0n%C3%B6n%C3%BC" title="İsmet İnönü">İnönü</a> and <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Churchill</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Second_Cairo_Conference" title="Second Cairo Conference">Second Cairo Conference</a>, 1943.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Democrat_Party_(Turkey,_1946%E2%80%9361)" class="mw-redirect" title="Democrat Party (Turkey, 1946–61)">Democratic Party</a> established by <a href="/wiki/Cel%C3%A2l_Bayar" title="Celâl Bayar">Celâl Bayar</a> won the <a href="/wiki/1950_Turkish_general_election" title="1950 Turkish general election">1950</a>, <a href="/wiki/1954_Turkish_general_election" title="1954 Turkish general election">1954</a> and <a href="/wiki/1957_Turkish_general_election" title="1957 Turkish general election">1957</a> general elections and stayed in power for a decade, with <a href="/wiki/Adnan_Menderes" title="Adnan Menderes">Adnan Menderes</a> as the Prime Minister and Bayar as the President. After fighting as part of the United Nations forces in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a>, Turkey joined <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> in 1952, becoming a bulwark against Soviet expansion into the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Basin" title="Mediterranean Basin">Mediterranean</a>. Turkey subsequently became a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a> in 1961, and an <a href="/wiki/Ankara_Agreement" title="Ankara Agreement">associate member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">EEC</a> in 1963.<sup id="cite_ref-oecd.org_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oecd.org-100">[98]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The country's tumultuous transition to <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_period_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Multi-party period of the Republic of Turkey">multiparty democracy</a> was interrupted by military <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'état">coups d'état</a> in <a href="/wiki/1960_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1960 Turkish coup d'état">1960</a> and <a href="/wiki/1980_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1980 Turkish coup d'état">1980</a>, as well as by military memorandums in <a href="/wiki/1971_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" class="mw-redirect" title="1971 Turkish coup d'état">1971</a> and <a href="/wiki/1997_military_memorandum_(Turkey)" class="mw-redirect" title="1997 military memorandum (Turkey)">1997</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-TRPoliticsandMilitary_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TRPoliticsandMilitary-101">[99]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[100]</a></sup> Between 1960 and the end of the 20th century, the prominent leaders in Turkish politics who achieved multiple election victories were <a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCleyman_Demirel" title="Süleyman Demirel">Süleyman Demirel</a>, <a href="/wiki/B%C3%BClent_Ecevit" title="Bülent Ecevit">Bülent Ecevit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turgut_%C3%96zal" title="Turgut Özal">Turgut Özal</a>. </p>
      <p>Following a decade of <a href="/wiki/Cypriot_intercommunal_violence" title="Cypriot intercommunal violence">Cypriot intercommunal violence</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1974_Cypriot_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1974 Cypriot coup d'état">coup in Cyprus on 15 July 1974</a> staged by the <a href="/wiki/EOKA_B" title="EOKA B">EOKA B</a> paramilitary organisation, which overthrew President <a href="/wiki/Makarios_III" title="Makarios III">Makarios</a> and installed the pro-<a href="/wiki/Enosis" title="Enosis">Enosis</a> (union with Greece) <a href="/wiki/Nikos_Sampson" title="Nikos Sampson">Nikos Sampson</a> as dictator, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_invasion_of_Cyprus" title="Turkish invasion of Cyprus">Turkey invaded Cyprus</a> on 20 July 1974 by unilaterally exercising Article IV in the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Guarantee_(1960)" title="Treaty of Guarantee (1960)">Treaty of Guarantee (1960)</a>, but without restoring the <a href="/wiki/Status_quo_ante_bellum" title="Status quo ante bellum">status quo ante</a> at the end of the military operation.<sup id="cite_ref-Uslu2003_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Uslu2003-103">[101]</a></sup> In 1983 the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Republic_of_Northern_Cyprus" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus">Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus</a>, which is recognised only by Turkey, was established.<sup id="cite_ref-trnc_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-trnc-104">[102]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Annan_Plan_for_Cyprus" class="mw-redirect" title="Annan Plan for Cyprus">Annan Plan</a> for reunifying the island was supported by the majority of <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Cypriots" title="Turkish Cypriots">Turkish Cypriots</a>, but rejected by the majority of <a href="/wiki/Greek_Cypriots" title="Greek Cypriots">Greek Cypriots</a>, in separate <a href="/wiki/2004_Cypriot_Annan_Plan_referendums" title="2004 Cypriot Annan Plan referendums">referendums in 2004</a>. However, negotiations for solving the <a href="/wiki/Cyprus_dispute" title="Cyprus dispute">Cyprus dispute</a> are still ongoing between Turkish Cypriot and Greek Cypriot political leaders.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[103]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Kurdish%E2%80%93Turkish_conflict_(1978%E2%80%93present)" title="Kurdish–Turkish conflict (1978–present)">conflict</a> between Turkey and the <a href="/wiki/Kurdistan_Workers%27_Party" title="Kurdistan Workers' Party">PKK</a> (designated a <a href="/wiki/List_of_designated_terrorist_groups" title="List of designated terrorist groups">terrorist organisation</a> by Turkey, the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-department-of-state-list_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-department-of-state-list-106">[104]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a><sup id="cite_ref-european-council-list_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-european-council-list-107">[105]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Treaty_Organization" class="mw-redirect" title="North Atlantic Treaty Organization">NATO</a><sup id="cite_ref-mfa-pkk_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mfa-pkk-108">[106]</a></sup>) has been active since 1984, primarily in the southeast of the country. More than 40,000 people have died as a result of the conflict.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[107]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[108]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[109]</a></sup> In 1999 PKK's founder <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_%C3%96calan" title="Abdullah Öcalan">Abdullah Öcalan</a> was arrested and sentenced for <a href="/wiki/Terrorism" title="Terrorism">terrorism</a><sup id="cite_ref-department-of-state-list_106-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-department-of-state-list-106">[104]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-european-council-list_107-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-european-council-list-107">[105]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Treason" title="Treason">treason</a> charges.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-29-06-1999_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-29-06-1999-112">[110]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bbc-03-10-2002_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-03-10-2002-113">[111]</a></sup> In the past, various <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Kurdish people">Kurdish</a> groups have unsuccessfully sought <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_separatism" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethnic separatism">separation</a> from Turkey to create an independent <a href="/wiki/Kurdistan" title="Kurdistan">Kurdish state</a>, while others have more recently pursued provincial <a href="/wiki/Autonomy" title="Autonomy">autonomy</a> and greater <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_of_Kurdish_people_in_Turkey" title="Human rights of Kurdish people in Turkey">political and cultural rights</a> for Kurds in Turkey. In the 21st century some reforms have taken place to improve the cultural rights of ethnic minorities in Turkey, such as the establishment of <a href="/wiki/TRT_Kurd%C3%AE" title="TRT Kurdî">TRT Kurdî</a>, <a href="/wiki/TRT_Arabi" title="TRT Arabi">TRT Arabi</a> and <a href="/wiki/TRT_Avaz" title="TRT Avaz">TRT Avaz</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Radio_and_Television_Corporation" title="Turkish Radio and Television Corporation">TRT</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:An%C4%B1tkabir.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/An%C4%B1tkabir.JPG/220px-An%C4%B1tkabir.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/An%C4%B1tkabir.JPG/330px-An%C4%B1tkabir.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/An%C4%B1tkabir.JPG/440px-An%C4%B1tkabir.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2816" data-file-height="2112"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:An%C4%B1tkabir.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/An%C4%B1tkabir" title="Anıtkabir">Anıtkabir</a>, the mausoleum of <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">Mustafa Kemal Atatürk</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a>, is visited by large crowds every year during national holidays, such as Republic Day on 29 October.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Since the liberalisation of the Turkish economy in the 1980s, the country has enjoyed stronger economic growth and greater political stability.<sup id="cite_ref-80sLiberalization_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80sLiberalization-114">[112]</a></sup> Turkey applied for full membership of the EEC in 1987, joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">EU Customs Union</a> in 1995 and started <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">accession negotiations</a> with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-TR_EUChrono_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TR_EUChrono-115">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-barroso_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-barroso-116">[114]</a></sup> In a non-binding vote on 13 March 2019, the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> called on the EU governments to suspend EU accession talks with Turkey, citing violations of human rights and the rule of law; but the negotiations, effectively on hold since 2018, remain active as of 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-dw-13-03-2019_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dw-13-03-2019-117">[115]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2013, <a href="/wiki/2013_protests_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="2013 protests in Turkey">widespread protests</a> erupted in many Turkish provinces, sparked by a plan to demolish <a href="/wiki/Gezi_Park" class="mw-redirect" title="Gezi Park">Gezi Park</a> but soon growing into general anti-government dissent.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[116]</a></sup> On 15 July 2016, an <a href="/wiki/2016_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt">unsuccessful coup attempt</a> tried to oust the government.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[117]</a></sup> As a reaction to the failed coup d'état, the government carried out <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Turkish_purges" class="mw-redirect" title="2016–17 Turkish purges">mass purges</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes.comxx_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes.comxx-120">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-turkeypurge.com_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-turkeypurge.com-121">[119]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Between 9 October – 25 November 2019, Turkey conducted a <a href="/wiki/2019_Turkish_offensive_into_north-eastern_Syria" title="2019 Turkish offensive into north-eastern Syria">military offensive into north-eastern Syria</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[121]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[122]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Turkey" title="Administrative divisions of Turkey">Administrative divisions of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Regions of Turkey">Regions of Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/NUTS_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="NUTS of Turkey">NUTS of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Turkey has a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> structure in terms of administration and this aspect is one of the most important factors shaping the Turkish public administration. When three powers (executive, legislative and judiciary) are taken into account as the main functions of the state, local administrations have little power. Turkey does not have a <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">federal</a> system, and the provinces are subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Central_government" title="Central government">central government</a> in Ankara. Local administrations were established to provide services in place and the government is represented by the province governors (<i>vali</i>) and town governors (<i>kaymakam</i>). Other senior public officials are also appointed by the central government instead of the mayors (<i>belediye başkanı</i>) or elected by constituents.<sup id="cite_ref-justice.gov.tr_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-justice.gov.tr-125">[123]</a></sup> Turkish municipalities have local legislative bodies (<i>belediye meclisi</i>) for decision-making on municipal issues. </p>
      <p>Within this unitary framework, Turkey is subdivided into 81 <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Turkey" title="Provinces of Turkey">provinces</a> (<i>il</i> or <i>vilayet</i>) for administrative purposes. Each province is divided into <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Districts of Turkey">districts</a> (<i>ilçe</i>), for a total of 973 districts.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[124]</a></sup> Turkey is also subdivided into 7 <a href="/wiki/Geographical_regions_of_Turkey" title="Geographical regions of Turkey">regions</a> (<i>bölge</i>) and 21 subregions for geographic, demographic and economic purposes; this does not refer to an administrative division. </p> 
      <div class="center">

        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute; left:657.6px; top:235.6px">
         <a href="/wiki/Hakk%C3%A2ri_Province" title="Hakkâri Province">Hakkâri</a>
        </div> 
        <div class="floatright">
         <a href="/wiki/Template:Turkey_Labelled_Map" title="Template:Turkey Labelled Map"><img alt="Desc-i.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Desc-i.svg/20px-Desc-i.svg.png" decoding="async" width="20" height="20" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Desc-i.svg/30px-Desc-i.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Desc-i.svg/40px-Desc-i.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="648" data-file-height="648"></a>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Turkey" title="Politics of Turkey">Politics of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">Constitution of Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Turkey" title="Elections in Turkey">Elections in Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ministries_of_Turkey" title="Ministries of Turkey">Ministries of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright" style="">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:162px">
        <div class="thumbimage noresize" style="width:160px;"> <a href="/wiki/File:Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan_2018_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan 2019 (cropped).jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg/160px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="160" height="216" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg/240px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg/320px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="647" data-file-height="873"></a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div style="text-align:center;">
          <a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">Recep Tayyip Erdoğan</a>
          <br><small><a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">President</a></small>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Between 1923 and 2018, Turkey was a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary</a> <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democracy</a>. A <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential system</a> was adopted by <a href="/wiki/2017_Turkish_constitutional_referendum" title="2017 Turkish constitutional referendum">referendum in 2017</a>; the new system came into effect with the <a href="/wiki/2018_Turkish_presidential_election" title="2018 Turkish presidential election">presidential election in 2018</a> and gives the President complete control of the <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive</a>, including the power to issue decrees, appoint his own cabinet, draw up the budget, dissolve parliament by calling early elections, and make appointments to the bureaucracy and the courts.<sup id="cite_ref-EconPres2018_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EconPres2018-127">[125]</a></sup> The office of <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Turkey" title="Prime Minister of Turkey">Prime Minister</a> has been abolished and its powers (together with those of the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Turkey" title="Cabinet of Turkey">Cabinet</a>) have been transferred to the President, who is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and is elected for a five-year term by direct elections.<sup id="cite_ref-EconPres2018_127-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EconPres2018-127">[125]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">Recep Tayyip Erdoğan</a> is the first president elected by direct voting. <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">Turkey's constitution</a> governs the legal framework of the country. It sets out the main principles of government and establishes Turkey as a unitary centralised state. </p>
      <p>Executive power is exercised by the President, while the <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">legislative</a> power is vested in the unicameral parliament, called the Grand National Assembly of Turkey. The <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">judiciary</a> is nominally independent from the executive and the legislature, but the constitutional changes that came into effect with the referendums in <a href="/wiki/2007_Turkish_constitutional_referendum" title="2007 Turkish constitutional referendum">2007</a>, <a href="/wiki/2010_Turkish_constitutional_referendum" title="2010 Turkish constitutional referendum">2010</a> and 2017 gave larger powers to the President and the <a href="/wiki/Ruling_party" title="Ruling party">ruling party</a> for appointing or dismissing <a href="/wiki/Judge" title="Judge">judges</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prosecutor" title="Prosecutor">prosecutors</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[126]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Turkey" title="Constitutional Court of Turkey">Constitutional Court</a> is charged with ruling on the conformity of <a href="/wiki/Legal_System_in_the_Republic_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Legal System in the Republic of Turkey">laws and decrees</a> with the constitution. The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Council_of_State" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Council of State">Council of State</a> is the tribunal of last resort for administrative cases, and the <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Appeals_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="High Court of Appeals of Turkey">High Court of Appeals</a> for all others.<sup id="cite_ref-TR_Constit_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TR_Constit-129">[127]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey_MPs_in_June_2015.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey_MPs_in_June_2015.jpg/300px-Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey_MPs_in_June_2015.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey_MPs_in_June_2015.jpg/450px-Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey_MPs_in_June_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey_MPs_in_June_2015.jpg/600px-Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey_MPs_in_June_2015.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="505"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey_MPs_in_June_2015.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">Grand National Assembly of Turkey</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">Universal suffrage</a> for both sexes has been applied throughout Turkey since 1933 and before most countries, and every Turkish citizen who has turned 18 years of age has the right to vote. There are 600 <a href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Member of Parliament">members of parliament</a> who are elected for a four-year term by a <a href="/wiki/Party-list_proportional_representation" title="Party-list proportional representation">party-list proportional representation</a> system from 85 electoral districts. The Constitutional Court can strip the public financing of <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Turkey" title="List of political parties in Turkey">political parties</a> that it deems <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">anti-secular</a> or <a href="/wiki/Separatism" title="Separatism">separatist</a>, or ban their existence altogether.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[128]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[129]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Electoral_threshold" title="Electoral threshold">electoral threshold</a> is ten percent of the votes.<sup id="cite_ref-BYEGM_TrPolSys_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BYEGM_TrPolSys-132">[130]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Supporters of Atatürk's reforms are called <a href="/wiki/Kemalism" title="Kemalism">Kemalists</a>, as distinguished from <a href="/wiki/Islamism" title="Islamism">Islamists</a>, representing the two diverging views regarding the role of religion in <a href="/wiki/Legislation" title="Legislation">legislation</a>, education and public life.<sup id="cite_ref-FleetFaroqhi2008p357_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FleetFaroqhi2008p357-133">[131]</a></sup> The Kemalist view supports a form of <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democracy</a> with a secular <a href="/wiki/Constitution" title="Constitution">constitution</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Westernised culture</a>, while maintaining the necessity of <a href="/wiki/State_intervention" class="mw-redirect" title="State intervention">state intervention</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Economy" title="Economy">economy</a>, education and other <a href="/wiki/Public_service" title="Public service">public services</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FleetFaroqhi2008p357_133-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FleetFaroqhi2008p357-133">[131]</a></sup> Since its foundation as a republic in 1923, Turkey has developed a strong tradition of <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secularism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-TR_Secularism_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TR_Secularism-134">[132]</a></sup> However, since the 1980s, issues such as income inequality and class distinction have given rise to Islamism, a movement that supports a larger role for religion in government policies, and in theory supports obligation to authority, communal solidarity and social justice; though what that entails in practice is often contested.<sup id="cite_ref-FleetFaroqhi2008p357_133-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FleetFaroqhi2008p357-133">[131]</a></sup> Turkey under Recep Tayyip Erdoğan and the AKP has been described as becoming increasingly <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[133]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[136]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law">Law</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Turkey" title="Judicial system of Turkey">Judicial system of Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Turkey" title="Law enforcement in Turkey">Law enforcement in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_(1).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg/240px-PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg/360px-PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg/480px-PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3752" data-file-height="2486"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_(1).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Istanbul_%C3%87a%C4%9Flayan_Justice_Palace" title="Istanbul Çağlayan Justice Palace">Istanbul Çağlayan Justice Palace</a> is a courthouse in the <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ei%C5%9Fli" title="Şişli">Şişli</a> district of <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Turkey" title="Judicial system of Turkey">Turkey's judicial system</a> has been wholly integrated with the <a href="/wiki/Law_in_Europe" title="Law in Europe">system of continental Europe</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="&quot;Has been&quot; is confusing as not clear whether still integrated. Should this be &quot;used to&quot;? As not integrated with EU law now. (March 2020)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> For instance, the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_civil_code_(1926)" title="Turkish civil code (1926)">Turkish Civil Code</a> has been modified by incorporating elements mainly of the <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Civil_Code" title="Swiss Civil Code">Swiss Civil Code</a> and <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Code_of_Obligations" title="Swiss Code of Obligations">Code of Obligations</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Germany" title="Law of Germany">German Commercial Code</a>. The Administrative Code bears similarities with its <a href="/wiki/Law_of_France" title="Law of France">French counterpart</a>, and the Penal Code with its <a href="/wiki/Italian_law_codes" title="Italian law codes">Italian counterpart</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-mymerhaba.com_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mymerhaba.com-139">[137]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Turkey has adopted the principle of the separation of powers. In line with this principle, judicial power is exercised by independent courts on behalf of the Turkish nation. The independence and organisation of the courts, the security of the tenure of judges and public prosecutors, the profession of judges and prosecutors, the supervision of judges and public prosecutors, the military courts and their organisation, and the powers and duties of the high courts are regulated by the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Constitution">Turkish Constitution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr-140">[138]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to Article 142 of the Turkish Constitution, the organisation, duties and jurisdiction of the courts, their functions and the trial procedures are regulated by law. In line with the aforementioned article of the Turkish Constitution and related laws, the court system in Turkey can be classified under three main categories; which are the Judicial Courts, Administrative Courts and Military Courts. Each category includes first instance courts and high courts. In addition, the Court of Jurisdictional Disputes rules on cases that cannot be classified readily as falling within the purview of one court system.<sup id="cite_ref-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr_140-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr-140">[138]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Law enforcement in Turkey is carried out by several departments (such as the <a href="/wiki/General_Directorate_of_Security" class="mw-redirect" title="General Directorate of Security">General Directorate of Security</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie_General_Command" title="Gendarmerie General Command">Gendarmerie General Command</a>) and agencies, all acting under the command of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">President of Turkey</a> or mostly the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of the Interior (Turkey)">Minister of Internal Affairs</a>. According to figures released by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Justice_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of Justice (Turkey)">Justice Ministry</a>, there are 100,000 people in <a href="/wiki/Turkish_prisons" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish prisons">Turkish prisons</a> as of November 2008, a doubling since 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[139]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title=" (March 2020)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>In the years of government by the AKP and Erdoğan, particularly since 2013, the independence and integrity of the Turkish judiciary has increasingly been said to be in doubt by institutions, parliamentarians and journalists both within and outside of Turkey; due to political interference in the promotion of judges and prosecutors, and in their pursuit of public duty.<sup id="cite_ref-EU2015_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU2015-142">[140]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EP2016_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EP2016-143">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-TI2016_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TI2016-144">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[143]</a></sup> The <i>Turkey 2015 report</i> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a> stated that "the independence of the judiciary and respect of the principle of separation of powers have been undermined and judges and prosecutors have been under strong political pressure."<sup id="cite_ref-EU2015_142-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU2015-142">[140]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Turkey" title="Foreign relations of Turkey">Foreign relations of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png/220px-EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="183" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png/330px-EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png/440px-EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>After becoming <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Council_of_Europe" title="Member states of the Council of Europe">one of the early members</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> in 1950, Turkey became an <a href="/wiki/Ankara_Agreement" title="Ankara Agreement">associate member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">EEC</a> in 1963, joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">EU Customs Union</a> in 1995 and started <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">full membership negotiations</a> with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-TR_EUChrono_115-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TR_EUChrono-115">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-barroso_116-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-barroso-116">[114]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Turkey is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> (1945),<sup id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign3_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign3-146">[144]</a></sup> the OECD (1961),<sup id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign1_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign1-147">[145]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">OIC</a> (1969),<sup id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign4_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign4-148">[146]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a> (1973),<sup id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign5_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign5-149">[147]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Economic_Cooperation_Organization" title="Economic Cooperation Organization">ECO</a> (1985),<sup id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign6_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign6-150">[148]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_the_Black_Sea_Economic_Cooperation" title="Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation">BSEC</a> (1992),<sup id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign7_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign7-151">[149]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Developing_8_Countries" class="mw-redirect" title="Developing 8 Countries">D-8</a> (1997)<sup id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign8_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign8-152">[150]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a> (1999).<sup id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign2_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign2-153">[151]</a></sup> Turkey was a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> in 1951–1952, 1954–1955, 1961 and 2009–2010.<sup id="cite_ref-Hürriyet_UN_Security_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hürriyet_UN_Security-154">[152]</a></sup> In 2012 Turkey became a dialogue partner of the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">SCO</a>, and in 2013 became a member of the <a href="/wiki/Asia_Cooperation_Dialogue" title="Asia Cooperation Dialogue">ACD</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-AFGTUR_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AFGTUR-155">[153]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-turkeyjoin_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-turkeyjoin-156">[154]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In line with its traditional Western orientation, relations with Europe have always been a central part of Turkish foreign policy. Turkey became <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Council_of_Europe" title="Member states of the Council of Europe">one of the early members</a> of the Council of Europe in 1950, applied for associate membership of the EEC (predecessor of the European Union) in 1959 and became an associate member in 1963. After decades of political negotiations, Turkey applied for full membership of the EEC in 1987, became an associate member of the <a href="/wiki/Western_European_Union" title="Western European Union">Western European Union</a> in 1992, joined the EU Customs Union in 1995 and has been in formal accession negotiations with the EU since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-TR_EUChrono_115-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TR_EUChrono-115">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-barroso_116-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-barroso-116">[114]</a></sup> Turkey's support for <a href="/wiki/Northern_Cyprus" title="Northern Cyprus">Northern Cyprus</a> in the Cyprus dispute complicates Turkey's relations with the EU and remains a major stumbling block to the country's EU accession bid.<sup id="cite_ref-Mardell_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mardell-157">[155]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The other defining aspect of Turkey's foreign policy was the country's long-standing strategic alliance with the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-foreignaffairs.com_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foreignaffairs.com-158">[156]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fas.org_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fas.org-159">[157]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Truman_Doctrine" title="Truman Doctrine">Truman Doctrine</a> in 1947 enunciated American intentions to guarantee the security of Turkey and Greece during the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, and resulted in large-scale <a href="/wiki/Turkey-United_States_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkey-United States relations">U.S. military and economic support</a>. In 1948 both countries were included in the <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">Marshall Plan</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_European_Economic_Co-operation" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for European Economic Co-operation">OEEC</a> for rebuilding European economies.<sup id="cite_ref-Truman_Doctrine_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Truman_Doctrine-160">[158]</a></sup> The common threat posed by the Soviet Union during the Cold War led to Turkey's membership of NATO in 1952, ensuring close bilateral relations with the US. Subsequently, Turkey benefited from the United States' political, economic and diplomatic support, including in key issues such as the country's bid to join the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[159]</a></sup> In the post–Cold War environment, Turkey's geostrategic importance shifted towards its proximity to the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> and the Balkans.<sup id="cite_ref-edoc.hu-berlin.de_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edoc.hu-berlin.de-162">[160]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg/220px-NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="122" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg/330px-NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg/440px-NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3683" data-file-height="2037"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="Turkish Armed Forces">Turkish Armed Forces</a> collectively rank as the second-largest standing military force in <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, after the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">US Armed Forces</a>. Turkey joined the alliance in <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_NATO#Original_and_joining_members" title="Member states of NATO">1952</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign-163">[161]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The independence of the <a href="/wiki/Turkic_states" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkic states">Turkic states</a> of the Soviet Union in 1991, with which Turkey shares a common cultural and linguistic heritage, allowed Turkey to extend its economic and political relations deep into <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Bal2004_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bal2004-164">[162]</a></sup> thus enabling the completion of a multi-billion-dollar oil and natural gas <a href="/wiki/Pipeline_transport" title="Pipeline transport">pipeline</a> from <a href="/wiki/Baku" title="Baku">Baku</a> in <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a> to the port of <a href="/wiki/Ceyhan" title="Ceyhan">Ceyhan</a> in Turkey. The <a href="/wiki/Baku%E2%80%93Tbilisi%E2%80%93Ceyhan_pipeline" title="Baku–Tbilisi–Ceyhan pipeline">Baku–Tbilisi–Ceyhan pipeline</a> forms part of Turkey's foreign policy strategy to become an energy conduit from the Caspian Sea basin to Europe. However, in 1993, Turkey sealed its land border with Armenia in a gesture of support to Azerbaijan (a Turkic state in the Caucasus region) during the <a href="/wiki/First_Nagorno-Karabakh_War" title="First Nagorno-Karabakh War">First Nagorno-Karabakh War</a>, and it remains closed.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[163]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a> in its turn put trade sanctions on Turkey after the <a href="/wiki/2020_Nagorno-Karabakh_war" title="2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war">2020 Nagorno-Karabakh War</a>. From December 31, 2020, imports from Turkey have been banned due to Turkey's support for Azerbaijan in the conflict.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[164]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Under the AKP government, Turkey's influence has grown in the formerly Ottoman territories of the Middle East and the Balkans, based on the "strategic depth" doctrine (a terminology that was coined by <a href="/wiki/Ahmet_Davuto%C4%9Flu" title="Ahmet Davutoğlu">Ahmet Davutoğlu</a> for defining Turkey's increased engagement in regional foreign policy issues), also called <a href="/wiki/Neo-Ottomanism" title="Neo-Ottomanism">Neo-Ottomanism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[166]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a> in December 2010, the choices made by the AKP government for supporting certain political opposition groups in the affected countries have led to tensions with some Arab states, such as Turkey's neighbour Syria since the start of the <a href="/wiki/Syrian_civil_war" title="Syrian civil war">Syrian civil war</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> after the <a href="/wiki/2013_Egyptian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="2013 Egyptian coup d'état">ousting of President Mohamed Morsi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[167]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[168]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_(Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_%28Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina%29.jpg/220px-Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_%28Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="130" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_%28Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina%29.jpg/330px-Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_%28Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_%28Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina%29.jpg/440px-Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_%28Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4227" data-file-height="2490"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_(Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/2015_G20_Antalya_summit" title="2015 G20 Antalya summit">2015 G20 Summit</a> held in <a href="/wiki/Antalya" title="Antalya">Antalya</a>, Turkey, a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> (1961) and <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a> (1999).
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Turkey does not have an ambassador in either Syria or Egypt.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[169]</a></sup> Diplomatic relations with <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a> were also severed after the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_flotilla_raid" title="Gaza flotilla raid">Gaza flotilla raid</a> in 2010, but were normalised following a deal in June 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[170]</a></sup> These political rifts have left Turkey with few allies in the <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">East Mediterranean</a>, where rich <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a> fields have recently been discovered;<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[172]</a></sup> in sharp contrast with the original goals that were set by the former Foreign Minister (later Prime Minister) Ahmet Davutoğlu in his "zero problems with neighbours"<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[173]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[174]</a></sup> foreign policy doctrine.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[175]</a></sup> In 2015, Turkey, <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a> formed a "strategic alliance" against Syrian President <a href="/wiki/Bashar_al-Assad" title="Bashar al-Assad">Bashar al-Assad</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[176]</a></sup> However, following the <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Turkey_relations#Normalisation_of_ties" title="Russia–Turkey relations">rapprochement with Russia</a> in 2016, Turkey revised its stance regarding the solution of the conflict in Syria.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[177]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[178]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[179]</a></sup> In January 2018, the Turkish military and the Turkish-backed forces, including the <a href="/wiki/Turkish-backed_Free_Syrian_Army" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army">Free Syrian Army</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ahrar_al-Sham" title="Ahrar al-Sham">Ahrar al-Sham</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[180]</a></sup> began an <a href="/wiki/Turkish_military_operation_in_Afrin" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish military operation in Afrin">intervention in Syria</a> aimed at ousting U.S.-backed <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Protection_Units" title="People's Protection Units">YPG</a> from the enclave of <a href="/wiki/Afrin,_Syria" title="Afrin, Syria">Afrin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[181]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[182]</a></sup> In 2020, Turkey openly <a href="/wiki/Turkish_military_intervention_in_the_Second_Libyan_Civil_War" title="Turkish military intervention in the Second Libyan Civil War">intervened in Libya</a> at the request of the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_National_Accord" title="Government of National Accord">GNA</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[183]</a></sup> There is a dispute over Turkey's <a href="/wiki/Aegean_dispute" title="Aegean dispute">maritime boundaries with Greece</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cyprus%E2%80%93Turkey_maritime_zones_dispute" title="Cyprus–Turkey maritime zones dispute">Cyprus</a> and drilling rights in the eastern Mediterranean.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[184]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[185]</a></sup> Turkey recognizes and supports the <a href="/wiki/Tripoli" title="Tripoli">Tripoli</a>-based <a href="/wiki/Government_of_National_Accord" title="Government of National Accord">Government of National Accord</a> (GNA) in <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a>, which has been torn by a <a href="/wiki/Libyan_Civil_War_(2014%E2%80%93present)" class="mw-redirect" title="Libyan Civil War (2014–present)">civil war</a> since 2014. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="Turkish Armed Forces">Turkish Armed Forces</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Defense_industry_of_Turkey" title="Defense industry of Turkey">Defense industry of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:ANKA_TUSAS.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/ANKA_TUSAS.jpg/220px-ANKA_TUSAS.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/ANKA_TUSAS.jpg/330px-ANKA_TUSAS.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/ANKA_TUSAS.jpg/440px-ANKA_TUSAS.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5234" data-file-height="3489"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:ANKA_TUSAS.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/TAI_Anka" title="TAI Anka">TAI Anka</a> is a family of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) developed by <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Aerospace_Industries" title="Turkish Aerospace Industries">Turkish Aerospace Industries</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="Turkish Armed Forces">Turkish Armed Forces</a> consist of the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Land_Forces" title="Turkish Land Forces">Land Forces</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Naval_Forces" title="Turkish Naval Forces">Naval Forces</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Air_Force" title="Turkish Air Force">Air Force</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Gendarmerie" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Gendarmerie">Gendarmerie</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Coast_Guard" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Coast Guard">Coast Guard</a> operate as parts of the Ministry of Internal Affairs in peacetime, although they are subordinated to the Army and Navy Commands respectively in wartime, during which they have both internal law-enforcement and military functions.<sup id="cite_ref-TSK_Organisation_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TSK_Organisation-188">[186]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chief_of_the_Turkish_General_Staff" title="Chief of the Turkish General Staff">Chief of the General Staff</a> is appointed by the President. The Council of Ministers is responsible to the Parliament for matters of national security and the adequate preparation of the armed forces to defend the country. However, the authority to declare war and to deploy the Turkish Armed Forces to foreign countries or to allow foreign armed forces to be stationed in Turkey rests solely with the Parliament.<sup id="cite_ref-TSK_Organisation_188-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TSK_Organisation-188">[186]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:TCG_Anadolu_(L-400).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/TCG_Anadolu_%28L-400%29.jpg/220px-TCG_Anadolu_%28L-400%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="100" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/TCG_Anadolu_%28L-400%29.jpg/330px-TCG_Anadolu_%28L-400%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/TCG_Anadolu_%28L-400%29.jpg/440px-TCG_Anadolu_%28L-400%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="545"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:TCG_Anadolu_(L-400).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/TCG_Anadolu" title="TCG Anadolu">TCG <i>Anadolu</i> (L-400)</a> <a href="/wiki/Amphibious_assault_ship" title="Amphibious assault ship">amphibious assault ship</a> (<a href="/wiki/Landing_helicopter_dock" title="Landing helicopter dock">LHD</a> and <a href="/wiki/V/STOL" title="V/STOL">V/STOL</a> <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">aircraft carrier</a>) at Sedef Shipyard in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>. The construction of a sister ship, to be named TCG <i>Trakya</i>, is currently being planned by the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Naval_Forces" title="Turkish Naval Forces">Turkish Navy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SavunmaSanayiST-2_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SavunmaSanayiST-2-189">[187]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DenizHaber1_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DenizHaber1-190">[188]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Every fit male Turkish citizen otherwise not barred is required to <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Turkey" title="Conscription in Turkey">serve in the military</a> for a period ranging from three weeks to a year, dependent on education and job location.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[189]</a></sup> Turkey does not recognise <a href="/wiki/Conscientious_objector" title="Conscientious objector">conscientious objection</a> and does not offer a <a href="/wiki/Alternative_civilian_service" title="Alternative civilian service">civilian alternative</a> to military service.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[190]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Turkey has the <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_NATO#Military_personnel" title="Member states of NATO">second-largest standing military force</a> in NATO, after the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">US Armed Forces</a>, with an estimated strength of 495,000 deployable forces, according to a 2011 NATO estimate.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[191]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title=" (March 2020)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup> Turkey is one of five NATO member states which are part of the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_sharing" title="Nuclear sharing">nuclear sharing</a> policy of the alliance, together with Belgium, <a href="/wiki/Germany_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Germany and weapons of mass destruction">Germany</a>, Italy, and the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Netherlands and weapons of mass destruction">Netherlands</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[192]</a></sup> A total of 90 <a href="/wiki/B61_nuclear_bomb" title="B61 nuclear bomb">B61 nuclear bombs</a> are hosted at the <a href="/wiki/Incirlik_Air_Base" title="Incirlik Air Base">Incirlik Air Base</a>, 40 of which are allocated for use by the Turkish Air Force in case of a nuclear conflict, but their use requires the approval of NATO.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[193]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Turkey has maintained forces in international missions under the United Nations and NATO since the Korean War, including <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> missions in <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Operation_in_Somalia_I" title="United Nations Operation in Somalia I">Somalia</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Protection_Force" title="United Nations Protection Force">Yugoslavia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Ocean_Shield" title="Operation Ocean Shield">Horn of Africa</a>. Turkey supported the <a href="/wiki/Coalition_of_the_Gulf_War" title="Coalition of the Gulf War">coalition forces</a> in the <a href="/wiki/First_Gulf_War" class="mw-redirect" title="First Gulf War">First Gulf War</a>. Turkish Armed Forces contribute military personnel to the <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">International Security Assistance Force</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Force" title="Kosovo Force">Kosovo Force</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurocorps" title="Eurocorps">Eurocorps</a> and <a href="/wiki/EU_Battlegroup" title="EU Battlegroup">EU Battlegroups</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Enter_the_EU_Battle_Groups_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Enter_the_EU_Battle_Groups-196">[194]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tskpeace_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tskpeace-197">[195]</a></sup> Turkey maintains a force of <a href="/wiki/Turkish_military_forces_in_Northern_Cyprus" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish military forces in Northern Cyprus">36,000 troops</a> in Northern Cyprus since 1974.<sup id="cite_ref-Richmond1998_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Richmond1998-198">[196]</a></sup> In recent years, Turkey has assisted <a href="/wiki/Peshmerga" title="Peshmerga">Peshmerga</a> forces in northern <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Somali_Armed_Forces" title="Somali Armed Forces">Somali Armed Forces</a> with security and training.<sup id="cite_ref-hurriyetdailynews.comq_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hurriyetdailynews.comq-199">[197]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-reuters.comq_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters.comq-200">[198]</a></sup> Turkish Armed Forces have <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_with_overseas_military_bases" title="List of countries with overseas military bases">overseas military bases</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pasha_Liman_Base" title="Pasha Liman Base">Albania</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-LarrabeeLesser94_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LarrabeeLesser94-201">[199]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Iraq%E2%80%93Turkey_relations#Turkish_military_presence_in_Iraq" title="Iraq–Turkey relations">Iraq</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[200]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Qatar%E2%80%93Turkey_relations#Turkish_military_presence_in_Qatar" title="Qatar–Turkey relations">Qatar</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[201]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Camp_TURKSOM" title="Camp TURKSOM">Somalia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[202]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Turkey" title="Human rights in Turkey">Human rights in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Racism_in_Turkey" title="Racism in Turkey">Racism in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Torture_in_Turkey" title="Torture in Turkey">Torture in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_Turkey" title="Censorship in Turkey">Censorship in Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%93present_purges_in_Turkey" title="2016–present purges in Turkey">2016–present purges in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg/220px-Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg/330px-Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg/440px-Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Women in Turkey protesting for their rights. On 20 March 2021, with a <a href="/wiki/Decree#Turkey" title="Decree">presidential decree</a>, Turkey withdrew from the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Convention" title="Istanbul Convention">Istanbul Convention</a>, which was ratified by the <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">Turkish parliament</a> in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-coe-ic_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-coe-ic-205">[203]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Turkey" title="Human rights in Turkey">human rights record of Turkey</a> has been the subject of much controversy and international condemnation. Between 1959 and 2011 the <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Human_Rights" title="European Court of Human Rights">European Court of Human Rights</a> made more than 2400 judgements against Turkey for human rights violations on issues such as <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_of_Kurdish_people_in_Turkey" title="Human rights of Kurdish people in Turkey">Kurdish rights</a>, <a href="/wiki/Women_in_Turkey" title="Women in Turkey">women's rights</a>, <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Turkey" title="LGBT rights in Turkey">LGBT rights</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Turkey">media freedom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ETCHR1_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ETCHR1-206">[204]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AnnualETCHR_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AnnualETCHR-207">[205]</a></sup> Turkey's human rights record continues to be a significant obstacle to the country's <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">membership of the EU</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[206]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the latter half of the 1970s, Turkey suffered from <a href="/wiki/Political_violence_in_Turkey_(1976%E2%80%931980)" title="Political violence in Turkey (1976–1980)">political violence</a> between <a href="/wiki/Far-left_politics" title="Far-left politics">far-left</a> and <a href="/wiki/Far-right_politics" title="Far-right politics">far-right</a> militant groups, which culminated in the <a href="/wiki/1980_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1980 Turkish coup d'état">military coup of 1980</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[207]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kurdistan_Workers%27_Party" title="Kurdistan Workers' Party">Kurdistan Workers' Party</a> (designated a <a href="/wiki/List_of_designated_terrorist_groups" title="List of designated terrorist groups">terrorist organisation</a> by Turkey, the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-department-of-state-list_106-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-department-of-state-list-106">[104]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a><sup id="cite_ref-european-council-list_107-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-european-council-list-107">[105]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Treaty_Organization" class="mw-redirect" title="North Atlantic Treaty Organization">NATO</a><sup id="cite_ref-mfa-pkk_108-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mfa-pkk-108">[106]</a></sup>) was founded in 1978 by a group of Kurdish militants led by <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_%C3%96calan" title="Abdullah Öcalan">Abdullah Öcalan</a>, seeking the foundation of an independent, <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">Marxist-Leninist state</a> in the region, which was to be known as Kurdistan.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[208]</a></sup> The initial reason given by the PKK for this was the oppression of Kurds in Turkey.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[209]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[210]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kurdish%E2%80%93Turkish_conflict_(1978%E2%80%93present)" title="Kurdish–Turkish conflict (1978–present)">A full-scale insurgency</a> began in 1984, when the PKK announced a Kurdish uprising. Following the arrest and imprisonment of Abdullah Öcalan in 1999,<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-29-06-1999_112-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-29-06-1999-112">[110]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bbc-03-10-2002_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-03-10-2002-113">[111]</a></sup> the PKK modified its demands into equal rights for ethnic Kurds and provincial autonomy within Turkey.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[211]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[212]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[213]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[214]</a></sup> Since the conflict began, more than 40,000 people have died, most of whom were Turkish Kurds.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[215]</a></sup> The European Court of Human Rights and other international human rights organisations have condemned Turkey for human rights abuses.<sup id="cite_ref-ETCHR1_206-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ETCHR1-206">[204]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AnnualETCHR_207-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AnnualETCHR-207">[205]</a></sup> Many judgments are related to cases such as civilian deaths in aerial bombardments,<sup id="cite_ref-hum1_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hum1-218">[216]</a></sup> torturing,<sup id="cite_ref-tort1_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tort1-219">[217]</a></sup> forced displacements,<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[218]</a></sup> destroyed villages,<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[219]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[220]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[221]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arbitrary_arrest" class="mw-redirect" title="Arbitrary arrest">arbitrary arrests</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[222]</a></sup> murdered and disappeared Kurdish journalists, activists and politicians.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[223]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Y%C3%BCksekda%C4%9F_and_Demirta%C5%9F.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Y%C3%BCksekda%C4%9F_and_Demirta%C5%9F.jpg/220px-Y%C3%BCksekda%C4%9F_and_Demirta%C5%9F.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="122" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Y%C3%BCksekda%C4%9F_and_Demirta%C5%9F.jpg/330px-Y%C3%BCksekda%C4%9F_and_Demirta%C5%9F.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Y%C3%BCksekda%C4%9F_and_Demirta%C5%9F.jpg/440px-Y%C3%BCksekda%C4%9F_and_Demirta%C5%9F.jpg 2x" data-file-width="581" data-file-height="323"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Y%C3%BCksekda%C4%9F_and_Demirta%C5%9F.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Opposition politicians <a href="/wiki/Selahattin_Demirtas" class="mw-redirect" title="Selahattin Demirtas">Selahattin Demirtas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Figen_Y%C3%BCksekda%C4%9F" title="Figen Yüksekdağ">Figen Yüksekdağ</a> were arrested on terrorism charges in 2016.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>On 20 May 2016, the Turkish parliament stripped almost a quarter of its members of <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_immunity" title="Parliamentary immunity">immunity</a> from prosecution, including 101 deputies from the pro-Kurdish <a href="/wiki/Peoples%27_Democratic_Party_(Turkey)" title="Peoples' Democratic Party (Turkey)">HDP</a> and the main opposition <a href="/wiki/Republican_People%27s_Party_(Turkey)" class="mw-redirect" title="Republican People's Party (Turkey)">CHP</a> party.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[224]</a></sup> In reaction to the <a href="/wiki/2016_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt">failed coup attempt</a> on 15 July 2016, over 160,000 judges, teachers, police and civil servants have been suspended or dismissed, 77,000 have been formally arrested,<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[225]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[226]</a></sup> and 130 media organisations, including 16 television broadcasters and 45 newspapers,<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[227]</a></sup> have been closed by the government of Turkey.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[228]</a></sup> 160 journalists have been imprisoned.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[229]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg/220px-Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg/330px-Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg/440px-Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4128" data-file-height="2322"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Turkish journalists protesting the <a href="/wiki/Turkey%27s_media_purge_after_the_failed_July_2016_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Turkey's media purge after the failed July 2016 coup d'état">imprisonment of their colleagues</a> on <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Day" title="Human Rights Day">Human Rights Day</a> in 2016.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Committee_to_Protect_Journalists" title="Committee to Protect Journalists">Committee to Protect Journalists</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Development_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice and Development Party (Turkey)">AKP</a> government has waged one of the world's biggest crackdowns on <a href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Media freedom in Turkey">media freedom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CPJ_232-0" class="reference"><a
