href="#cite_note-CPJ-232">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cpj.org1_233-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cpj.org1-233">[231]</a></sup> Many journalists have been arrested using charges of "terrorism" and "anti-state activities" such as the <a href="/wiki/Ergenekon_(organization)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ergenekon (organization)">Ergenekon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sledgehammer_(coup_plan)" title="Sledgehammer (coup plan)">Balyoz</a> cases, while thousands have been investigated on charges such as "denigrating Turkishness" or "insulting Islam" in an effort to sow self-censorship.<sup id="cite_ref-CPJ_232-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CPJ-232">[230]</a></sup> In 2017, the CPJ identified 81 jailed journalists in Turkey (including the editorial staff of <i><a href="/wiki/Cumhuriyet" title="Cumhuriyet">Cumhuriyet</a></i>, Turkey's oldest newspaper still in circulation), all directly held for their published work (the country ranked first in the world in that year, with more journalists in prison than in Iran, Eritrea or China);<sup id="cite_ref-cpj.org1_233-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cpj.org1-233">[231]</a></sup> while in 2015 Freemuse identified nine musicians imprisoned for their work (ranking third after Russia and China).<sup id="cite_ref-freemuse_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freemuse-234">[232]</a></sup> In 2015 Turkey's media was rated as <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_Press_(report)" title="Freedom of the Press (report)"><i>not free</i></a> by Freedom House.<sup id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-235">[233]</a></sup> In its resolution "The functioning of democratic institutions in Turkey" on 22 June 2016, the <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_Assembly_of_the_Council_of_Europe" title="Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe">Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe</a> warned that "recent developments in Turkey pertaining to freedom of the media and of expression, erosion of the rule of law and the human rights violations in relation to anti-terrorism security operations in south-east Turkey have (...) raised serious questions about the functioning of its democratic institutions."<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[234]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Renowned Turkish journalists who were murdered for their opinions include <a href="/wiki/Abdi_%C4%B0pek%C3%A7i" title="Abdi İpekçi">Abdi İpekçi</a> (1929–1979, editor-in-chief of <i><a href="/wiki/Milliyet" title="Milliyet">Milliyet</a></i>); <a href="/wiki/%C3%87etin_Eme%C3%A7" title="Çetin Emeç">Çetin Emeç</a> (1935–1990, chief columnist and coordinator of <i><a href="/wiki/H%C3%BCrriyet" title="Hürriyet">Hürriyet</a></i>); <a href="/wiki/U%C4%9Fur_Mumcu" title="Uğur Mumcu">Uğur Mumcu</a> (1942–1993, columnist and investigative journalist of <i><a href="/wiki/Cumhuriyet" title="Cumhuriyet">Cumhuriyet</a></i>); and <a href="/wiki/Hrant_Dink" title="Hrant Dink">Hrant Dink</a> (1954–2007, founder and editor-in-chief of <i><a href="/wiki/Agos" title="Agos">Agos</a></i>). </p>
      <p>During the October 2019 offensive into Syria, Turkish forces have been accused of <a href="/wiki/War_crimes" class="mw-redirect" title="War crimes">war crimes</a>, such as targeting civilians with <a href="/wiki/White_phosphorus" class="mw-redirect" title="White phosphorus">white phosphorus</a> and various other human rights violations.<sup id="cite_ref-tfsoa_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tfsoa-237">[235]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-taowc_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taowc-238">[236]</a></sup> Turkey has officially rejected the claims, with the Minister of Defense <a href="/wiki/Hulusi_Akar" title="Hulusi Akar">Hulusi Akar</a> stating that chemical weapons don't exist in the inventory of the Turkish Armed Forces.<sup id="cite_ref-TRT-World-07-11-2019_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TRT-World-07-11-2019-239">[237]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> stated that it had gathered evidence of war crimes and other violations committed by Turkish and Turkey-backed Syrian forces who are said to "have displayed a shameful disregard for civilian life, carrying out serious violations and war crimes, including summary killings and unlawful attacks that have killed and injured civilians".<sup id="cite_ref-amnesty1_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-amnesty1-240">[238]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="LGBT_rights">LGBT rights</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Turkey" title="LGBT rights in Turkey">LGBT rights in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Homosexual activity is legal in Turkey.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[239]</a></sup> However, LGBT people in Turkey face discrimination, harassment and even violence from their relatives, neighbors, etc.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[240]</a></sup> The Turkish authorities have carried out many discriminatory practices like the closure of LGBTI+ associations, raids on the homes of gay individuals, censuring of websites and magazines, etc.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[241]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[242]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[243]</a></sup> Despite these, the LGBT acceptance in Turkey is growing. In a survey conducted by the <a href="/wiki/Kadir_Has_University" title="Kadir Has University">Kadir Has University</a> in Istanbul in 2016, 33% of the respondents said that LGBT people should have equal rights, which increased to 45% in 2020. Another survey by Kadir Has University in 2018 found that the proportion of people who wouldn't want a homosexual neighbour decreased from 55.3% in 2018 to 46.5% in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[244]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[245]</a></sup> A poll by <a href="/wiki/Ipsos" title="Ipsos">Ipsos</a> in 2015 found that 27% of the Turkish public was in favor of legalizing same-sex marriage and 19% of supporting civil unions instead.<sup id="cite_ref-Ipsos_2015_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ipsos_2015-248">[246]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Turkey" title="Geography of Turkey">Geography of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Turkey" title="List of national parks of Turkey">List of national parks of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Turkey_topo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Turkey_topo.jpg/280px-Turkey_topo.jpg" decoding="async" width="280" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Turkey_topo.jpg/420px-Turkey_topo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Turkey_topo.jpg/560px-Turkey_topo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="752"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Turkey_topo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Topographic_map" title="Topographic map">Topographic map</a> of Turkey
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Turkey is a <a href="/wiki/Transcontinental_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Transcontinental country">transcontinental country</a> bridging <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Southeastern Europe">Southeastern Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a>. Asian Turkey, which includes 97 percent of the country's territory, is separated from <a href="/wiki/East_Thrace" title="East Thrace">European Turkey</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus" class="mw-redirect" title="Bosphorus">Bosphorus</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Marmara" title="Sea of Marmara">Sea of Marmara</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">Dardanelles</a>. European Turkey comprises only 3 percent of the country's territory.<sup id="cite_ref-turkeygeoth_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-turkeygeoth-249">[247]</a></sup> Turkey covers an area of 783,562 square kilometres (302,535 square miles),<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[248]</a></sup> of which 755,688 square kilometres (291,773 square miles) is in <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a> and 23,764 square kilometres (9,175 square miles) is in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-USLC_TRGeo_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USLC_TRGeo-251">[249]</a></sup> The country is encircled by seas on three sides: the Aegean Sea to the west, the Black Sea to the north and the Mediterranean Sea to the south. Turkey also contains the Sea of Marmara in the northwest.<sup id="cite_ref-TRGeo_TRMinistryTourism_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TRGeo_TRMinistryTourism-252">[250]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Turkey is divided into seven geographical regions: <a href="/wiki/Marmara_Region,_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Marmara Region, Turkey">Marmara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Region,_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Aegean Region, Turkey">Aegean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region,_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Black Sea Region, Turkey">Black Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region,_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Anatolia Region, Turkey">Central Anatolia</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_Anatolia_Region,_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="East Anatolia Region, Turkey">Eastern Anatolia</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Eastern_Anatolia_Region,_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="South Eastern Anatolia Region, Turkey">Southeastern Anatolia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea_Region,_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean Sea Region, Turkey">Mediterranean</a>. The uneven north Anatolian terrain running along the Black Sea resembles a long, narrow belt. This region comprises approximately one-sixth of Turkey's total land area. As a general trend, the inland Anatolian plateau becomes increasingly rugged as it progresses eastward.<sup id="cite_ref-TRGeo_TRMinistryTourism_252-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TRGeo_TRMinistryTourism-252">[250]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Balloons_At_Cappadocia_(58997524).jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Balloons_At_Cappadocia_%2858997524%29.jpeg/220px-Balloons_At_Cappadocia_%2858997524%29.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Balloons_At_Cappadocia_%2858997524%29.jpeg/330px-Balloons_At_Cappadocia_%2858997524%29.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Balloons_At_Cappadocia_%2858997524%29.jpeg/440px-Balloons_At_Cappadocia_%2858997524%29.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1396"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Balloons_At_Cappadocia_(58997524).jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Cappadocia" title="Cappadocia">Cappadocia</a> is a region created by the erosion of soft volcanic stone by the wind and rain for centuries.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>East Thrace; the European portion of Turkey, is located at the easternmost edge the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>. It forms the border between Turkey and its neighbours Greece and Bulgaria. The Asian part of the country mostly consists of the peninsula of <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>, which consists of a high central plateau with narrow coastal plains, between the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ro%C4%9Flu_Mountains" title="Köroğlu Mountains">Köroğlu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Mountains" title="Pontic Mountains">Pontic</a> mountain ranges to the north and the <a href="/wiki/Taurus_Mountains" title="Taurus Mountains">Taurus Mountains</a> to the south. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Eastern Anatolia Region">Eastern Anatolia Region</a> mostly corresponds to the western part of the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Highlands" title="Armenian Highlands">Armenian Highlands</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Plateau" title="Plateau">plateau</a> situated between the <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_Plateau" title="Anatolian Plateau">Anatolian Plateau</a> in the west and the <a href="/wiki/Lesser_Caucasus" title="Lesser Caucasus">Lesser Caucasus</a> in the north)<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[251]</a></sup> and contains <a href="/wiki/Mount_Ararat" title="Mount Ararat">Mount Ararat</a>, Turkey's highest point at 5,137 metres (16,854 feet),<sup id="cite_ref-mararat_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mararat-254">[252]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Van" title="Lake Van">Lake Van</a>, the largest lake in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-lvan_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lvan-255">[253]</a></sup> Eastern Turkey has a mountainous landscape and is home to the sources of rivers such as the <a href="/wiki/Euphrates" title="Euphrates">Euphrates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tigris" title="Tigris">Tigris</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aras_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Aras River">Aras</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Southeastern Anatolia Region">Southeastern Anatolia Region</a> includes the northern plains of <a href="/wiki/Upper_Mesopotamia" title="Upper Mesopotamia">Upper Mesopotamia</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Turkey" title="Wildlife of Turkey">Wildlife of Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Turkey" title="Fauna of Turkey">Fauna of Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Flora_and_vegetation_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Flora and vegetation of Turkey">Flora and vegetation of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Turkey" title="Environmental issues in Turkey">Environmental issues in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG/220px-Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG/330px-Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG/440px-Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="2592"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Sumela_Monastery" title="Sumela Monastery">Sumela Monastery</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Mountains" title="Pontic Mountains">Pontic Mountains</a>, which form an <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">ecoregion</a> with <a href="/wiki/Northern_Anatolian_conifer_and_deciduous_forests" title="Northern Anatolian conifer and deciduous forests">diverse temperate rainforest types</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flora" title="Flora">flora</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fauna" title="Fauna">fauna</a> in northern Anatolia.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Turkey's extraordinary <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystem</a> and habitat diversity has produced considerable species diversity.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[254]</a></sup> Anatolia is the homeland of many plants that have been cultivated for food since the advent of <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a>, and the wild ancestors of many plants that now provide staples for humankind still grow in Turkey. The diversity of <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Turkey" title="Fauna of Turkey">Turkey's fauna</a> is even greater than that of <a href="/wiki/Flora_and_vegetation_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Flora and vegetation of Turkey">its flora</a>. The number of animal species in the whole of Europe is around 60,000, while in Turkey there are over 80,000 (over 100,000 counting the subspecies).<sup id="cite_ref-allaboutturkey_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allaboutturkey-257">[255]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Northern_Anatolian_conifer_and_deciduous_forests" title="Northern Anatolian conifer and deciduous forests">Northern Anatolian conifer and deciduous forests</a> is an <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">ecoregion</a> which covers most of the <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Mountains" title="Pontic Mountains">Pontic Mountains</a> in northern Turkey, while the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus_mixed_forests" title="Caucasus mixed forests">Caucasus mixed forests</a> extend across the eastern end of the range. The region is home to <a href="/wiki/Eurasia" title="Eurasia">Eurasian</a> wildlife such as the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_sparrowhawk" title="Eurasian sparrowhawk">Eurasian sparrowhawk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Golden_eagle" title="Golden eagle">golden eagle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_imperial_eagle" title="Eastern imperial eagle">eastern imperial eagle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lesser_spotted_eagle" title="Lesser spotted eagle">lesser spotted eagle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caucasian_black_grouse" class="mw-redirect" title="Caucasian black grouse">Caucasian black grouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Red-fronted_serin" title="Red-fronted serin">red-fronted serin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wallcreeper" title="Wallcreeper">wallcreeper</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[256]</a></sup> The narrow coastal strip between the Pontic Mountains and the Black Sea is home to the <a href="/wiki/Euxine-Colchic_deciduous_forests" class="mw-redirect" title="Euxine-Colchic deciduous forests">Euxine-Colchic deciduous forests</a>, which contain some of the world's few <a href="/wiki/Temperate_rainforest" title="Temperate rainforest">temperate rainforests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[257]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_pine" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish pine">Turkish pine</a> is mostly found in Turkey and other east Mediterranean countries. Several wild species of <a href="/wiki/Tulip" title="Tulip">tulip</a> are native to Anatolia, and the flower was first <a href="/wiki/Tulip#Introduction_to_Western_Europe" title="Tulip">introduced to Western Europe</a> with species taken from the Ottoman Empire in the 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Blunt_7_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Blunt_7-260">[258]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[259]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg/200px-Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg/300px-Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg/400px-Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A white <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Angora" title="Turkish Angora">Turkish Angora</a> cat with <a href="/wiki/Odd-eyed_cat" title="Odd-eyed cat">odd eyes (heterochromia)</a>, which is common among the Angoras.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>There are <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Turkey" title="List of national parks of Turkey">40 national parks</a>, 189 nature parks, 31 nature preserve areas, 80 wildlife protection areas and 109 nature monuments in Turkey such as <a href="/wiki/Gallipoli_Peninsula_Historical_National_Park" class="mw-redirect" title="Gallipoli Peninsula Historical National Park">Gallipoli Peninsula Historical National Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Nemrut_National_Park" class="mw-redirect" title="Mount Nemrut National Park">Mount Nemrut National Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Troy" title="Troy">Ancient Troy National Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%96l%C3%BCdeniz_Nature_Park" class="mw-redirect" title="Ölüdeniz Nature Park">Ölüdeniz Nature Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polonezk%C3%B6y_Nature_Park" title="Polonezköy Nature Park">Polonezköy Nature Park</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ministryofforest_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforest-262">[260]</a></sup> In the 21st century, threats to biodiversity include <a href="/wiki/Desertification" title="Desertification">desertification</a> due to <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Turkey" title="Climate change in Turkey">climate change in Turkey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[261]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_leopard" class="mw-redirect" title="Anatolian leopard">Anatolian leopard</a> is still found in very small numbers in the northeastern and southeastern regions of Turkey.<sup id="cite_ref-O.E.Can_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-O.E.Can-264">[262]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[263]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_lynx" title="Eurasian lynx">Eurasian lynx</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_wildcat" title="European wildcat">European wildcat</a> are other <a href="/wiki/Felidae" title="Felidae">felid</a> species which are currently found in the forests of Turkey. The <a href="/wiki/Caspian_tiger" title="Caspian tiger">Caspian tiger</a>, now extinct, lived in the easternmost regions of Turkey until the latter half of the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-O.E.Can_264-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-O.E.Can-264">[262]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Üstay_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Üstay-266">[264]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Renowned domestic animals from <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a>, the capital of Turkey, include the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Angora" title="Turkish Angora">Angora cat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Angora_rabbit" title="Angora rabbit">Angora rabbit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Angora_goat" title="Angora goat">Angora goat</a>; and from <a href="/wiki/Van_Province" title="Van Province">Van Province</a> the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Van" title="Turkish Van">Van cat</a>. The national dog breeds are the <a href="/wiki/Kangal_Shepherd_Dog" title="Kangal Shepherd Dog">Kangal</a> (<a href="/wiki/Anatolian_Shepherd" class="mw-redirect" title="Anatolian Shepherd">Anatolian Shepherd</a>), <a href="/wiki/Aksaray_Malaklisi_dog" class="mw-redirect" title="Aksaray Malaklisi dog">Malaklı</a> and <a href="/wiki/Akbash_Dog" class="mw-redirect" title="Akbash Dog">Akbaş</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gateofturkey_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gateofturkey-267">[265]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Turkey" title="Climate of Turkey">Climate of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Turkey" title="Climate change in Turkey">Climate change in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg/250px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="117" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg/375px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg/500px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1816" data-file-height="850"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> of Turkey
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The coastal areas of Turkey bordering the Aegean and Mediterranean Seas have a <a href="/wiki/Temperate" class="mw-redirect" title="Temperate">temperate</a> <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a>, with hot, dry summers and mild to cool, wet winters.<sup id="cite_ref-Meteo_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-268">[266]</a></sup> The coastal areas bordering the Black Sea have a temperate <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a> with warm, wet summers and cool to cold, wet <a href="/wiki/Winter" title="Winter">winters</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Meteo_268-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-268">[266]</a></sup> The Turkish Black Sea coast receives the greatest amount of <a href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">precipitation</a> and is the only region of Turkey that receives high precipitation throughout the year.<sup id="cite_ref-Meteo_268-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-268">[266]</a></sup> The eastern part of that coast averages 2,200 millimetres (87&nbsp;in) annually which is the highest precipitation in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Meteo_268-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-268">[266]</a></sup> </p>
      <p> The coastal areas bordering the Sea of Marmara, which connects the Aegean Sea and the Black Sea, have a transitional climate between a temperate Mediterranean climate and a temperate oceanic climate with warm to hot, moderately dry <a href="/wiki/Summer" title="Summer">summers</a> and cool to cold, wet winters.<sup id="cite_ref-Meteo_268-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-268">[266]</a></sup> Snow falls on the coastal areas of the Sea of Marmara and the Black Sea almost every winter, but usually melts in no more than a few days.<sup id="cite_ref-Meteo_268-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-268">[266]</a></sup> However snow is rare in the coastal areas of the Aegean Sea and very rare in the coastal areas of the Mediterranean Sea.<sup id="cite_ref-Meteo_268-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-268">[266]</a></sup></p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_(Sensoy,_S._et_al,_2008).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_%28Sensoy%2C_S._et_al%2C_2008%29.png/220px-Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_%28Sensoy%2C_S._et_al%2C_2008%29.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_%28Sensoy%2C_S._et_al%2C_2008%29.png/330px-Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_%28Sensoy%2C_S._et_al%2C_2008%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_%28Sensoy%2C_S._et_al%2C_2008%29.png/440px-Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_%28Sensoy%2C_S._et_al%2C_2008%29.png 2x" data-file-width="1306" data-file-height="797"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_(Sensoy,_S._et_al,_2008).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Climate diagram of Turkey<sup id="cite_ref-Meteo_268-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-268">[266]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>Mountains close to the coast prevent Mediterranean influences from extending inland, giving the central Anatolian <a href="/wiki/Plateau" title="Plateau">plateau</a> of the interior of Turkey a <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental climate</a> with sharply contrasting <a href="/wiki/Seasons" class="mw-redirect" title="Seasons">seasons</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Meteo_268-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-268">[266]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Winters on the plateau are especially severe. Temperatures of −30&nbsp;°C to −40&nbsp;°C (−22&nbsp;°F to −40&nbsp;°F) do occur in northeastern Anatolia, and snow may lie on the ground at least 120 days of the year and in the mountains almost the entire year. In central Anatolia the temperatures can drop below -20&nbsp;°C ( -4&nbsp;°F) with the mountains being even colder. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Turkey" title="Economy of Turkey">Economy of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_currency_and_debt_crisis,_2018" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish currency and debt crisis, 2018">Turkish currency and debt crisis, 2018</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg/220px-View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg/330px-View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg/440px-View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2106"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Skyscrapers in the <a href="/wiki/Levent" title="Levent">Levent</a> quarter of the <a href="/wiki/Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F" title="Beşiktaş">Beşiktaş</a> district on the European side of <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>, the largest city and financial centre in Turkey.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Turkey is a <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized country</a>, with an upper-middle income economy, which is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">twentieth-largest in the world</a> by nominal GDP, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">eleventh-largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>. According to <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> estimates, Turkey's GDP per capita by PPP is $32,278 in 2021,<sup id="cite_ref-IMF-WEO_8-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMF-WEO-8">[8]</a></sup> and approximately 14.4% of Turks lived <a href="/wiki/Poverty_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Poverty by country">below the national poverty line</a> in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[267]</a></sup> Unemployment in Turkey was 13.6% in 2019,<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[268]</a></sup> and the middle class population in Turkey rose from 18% to 41% of the population between 1993 and 2010 according to the World Bank.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[269]</a></sup> As of January&nbsp;2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, foreign reserves in Turkey are worth $51 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[270]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/European_Union_%E2%80%93_Turkey_Customs_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="European Union – Turkey Customs Union">EU–Turkey Customs Union</a> in 1995 led to an extensive liberalisation of tariff rates, and forms one of the most important pillars of Turkey's foreign trade policy.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[271]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Turkey" title="Automotive industry in Turkey">automotive industry in Turkey</a> is sizeable, and produced over 1.3&nbsp;million motor vehicles in 2015, ranking as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_motor_vehicle_production" title="List of countries by motor vehicle production">14th largest producer in the world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-oica_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oica-274">[272]</a></sup> Turkish <a href="/wiki/Shipyard" title="Shipyard">shipyards</a> are highly regarded both for the production of chemical and <a href="/wiki/Oil_tanker" title="Oil tanker">oil tankers</a> up to 10,000 <a href="/wiki/Deadweight_tonnage" title="Deadweight tonnage">dwt</a> and also for their <a href="/wiki/Mega_yacht" class="mw-redirect" title="Mega yacht">mega yachts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ship-oecd_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ship-oecd-275">[273]</a></sup> Turkish brands like <a href="/wiki/Beko" title="Beko">Beko</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vestel" title="Vestel">Vestel</a> are among the largest producers of <a href="/wiki/Consumer_electronics" title="Consumer electronics">consumer electronics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Home_appliances" class="mw-redirect" title="Home appliances">home appliances</a> in Europe, and invest a substantial amount of funds for research and development in new technologies related to these fields.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[274]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[275]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[276]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Otokar_Territo_U_IAA_2016_(1)_Travelarz.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Otokar_Territo_U_IAA_2016_%281%29_Travelarz.JPG/170px-Otokar_Territo_U_IAA_2016_%281%29_Travelarz.JPG" decoding="async" width="170" height="128" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Otokar_Territo_U_IAA_2016_%281%29_Travelarz.JPG/255px-Otokar_Territo_U_IAA_2016_%281%29_Travelarz.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Otokar_Territo_U_IAA_2016_%281%29_Travelarz.JPG/340px-Otokar_Territo_U_IAA_2016_%281%29_Travelarz.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="3000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Otokar_Territo_U_IAA_2016_(1)_Travelarz.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Turkish automotive companies like <a href="/wiki/TEMSA" title="TEMSA">TEMSA</a>, <a href="/wiki/Otokar" title="Otokar">Otokar</a> and <a href="/wiki/BMC_(Turkey)" title="BMC (Turkey)">BMC</a> are among the world's largest van, bus and truck manufacturers.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Other key sectors of the Turkish economy are <a href="/wiki/List_of_banks_in_Turkey" title="List of banks in Turkey">banking</a>, construction, home appliances, electronics, textiles, oil refining, petrochemical products, food, mining, iron and steel, and <a href="/wiki/Machine_industry" title="Machine industry">machine industry</a>. However, agriculture still accounted for a quarter of employment.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[277]</a></sup> In 2004, it was estimated that 46 percent of total disposable income was received by the top 20 percent of income earners, while the lowest 20 percent received only 6 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[278]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">Foreign direct investment</a> (FDI) was $8.3&nbsp;billion in 2012, a figure expected to rise to $15&nbsp;billion in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[279]</a></sup> In the economic crisis of 2016 it emerged that the huge debts incurred for investment during the AKP government since 2002 had mostly been consumed in construction, rather than invested in sustainable economic growth.<sup id="cite_ref-how-to-ruin_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-how-to-ruin-282">[280]</a></sup> Turkey's gross external <a href="/wiki/National_debt_of_Turkey" title="National debt of Turkey">debt</a> reached $453.2&nbsp;billion at the end of December 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[281]</a></sup> Turkey's annual <a href="/wiki/Current_account_(balance_of_payments)" title="Current account (balance of payments)">current account</a> deficit was $47.3&nbsp;billion at the end of December 2017, compared to the previous year's figure of $33.1&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-deficit2017-2018_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-deficit2017-2018-284">[282]</a></sup> In 2020, according to <a href="/wiki/Carbon_Tracker" title="Carbon Tracker">Carbon Tracker</a>, money was being wasted constructing more <a href="/wiki/List_of_active_coal_fired_power_stations_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="List of active coal fired power stations in Turkey">coal-fired power stations in Turkey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[283]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Fatih_Birol" title="Fatih Birol">Fatih Birol</a> the head of the <a href="/wiki/International_Energy_Agency" title="International Energy Agency">International Energy Agency</a> said that <a href="/wiki/Energy_subsidy#Turkey" title="Energy subsidy">fossil fuel subsidies</a> should be redirected, for example to the <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Turkey" title="Health in Turkey">health system</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[284]</a></sup> Fossil fuel subsidies were around 0.2% of GDP for the first two decades of the 21st century,<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[285]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-288">[286]</a></sup> and are higher than clean <a href="/wiki/Energy_subsidies" class="mw-redirect" title="Energy subsidies">energy subsidies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[287]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/External_costs" class="mw-redirect" title="External costs">external costs</a> of fossil fuel consumption in 2018 has been estimated as 1.5% of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[288]</a></sup> In 2020 the <a href="/wiki/European_Bank_for_Reconstruction_and_Development" title="European Bank for Reconstruction and Development">European Bank for Reconstruction and Development</a> offered to support a <a href="/wiki/Just_transition" class="mw-redirect" title="Just transition">just transition</a> away from coal.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-291">[289]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Turkey" title="Tourism in Turkey">Tourism in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Marmaris_harbor_(aerial_view),_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province,_southwest_Turkey,_Mediterranean.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Marmaris_harbor_%28aerial_view%29%2C_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province%2C_southwest_Turkey%2C_Mediterranean.jpg/220px-Marmaris_harbor_%28aerial_view%29%2C_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province%2C_southwest_Turkey%2C_Mediterranean.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="96" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Marmaris_harbor_%28aerial_view%29%2C_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province%2C_southwest_Turkey%2C_Mediterranean.jpg/330px-Marmaris_harbor_%28aerial_view%29%2C_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province%2C_southwest_Turkey%2C_Mediterranean.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Marmaris_harbor_%28aerial_view%29%2C_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province%2C_southwest_Turkey%2C_Mediterranean.jpg/440px-Marmaris_harbor_%28aerial_view%29%2C_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province%2C_southwest_Turkey%2C_Mediterranean.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="1738"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Marmaris_harbor_(aerial_view),_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province,_southwest_Turkey,_Mediterranean.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Marmaris" title="Marmaris">Marmaris</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Riviera" title="Turkish Riviera">Turkish Riviera</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Turkey" title="Tourism in Turkey">Tourism in Turkey</a> has increased almost every year in the 21st century,<sup id="cite_ref-TourismStats2018_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TourismStats2018-292">[290]</a></sup> and is an important part of the economy. The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Ministry_of_Culture_and_Tourism" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Ministry of Culture and Tourism">Turkish Ministry of Culture and Tourism</a> currently promotes Turkish tourism under the project <a href="/wiki/Turkey_Home" title="Turkey Home">Turkey Home</a>. Turkey is one of the world's top ten destination countries, with the highest percentage of foreign visitors arriving from Europe; specially Germany and Russia in recent years.<sup id="cite_ref-TourismStats2018_292-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TourismStats2018-292">[290]</a></sup> In 2019, Turkey <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings#Most_visited_destinations_by_international_tourist_arrivals" title="World Tourism rankings">ranked sixth in the world</a> in terms of the number of international tourist arrivals, with 51.2 million foreign tourists visiting the country.<sup id="cite_ref-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2019_Edition_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2019_Edition-293">[291]</a></sup> Turkey has <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey">17 UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey_(Tentative_list)" class="mw-redirect" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey (Tentative list)">51 World Heritage Sites in tentative list</a> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Turkey" title="Transport in Turkey">Transport in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Communications_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Communications in Turkey">Communications in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Turkey" title="Energy in Turkey">Energy in Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Turkey" title="Water supply and sanitation in Turkey">Water supply and sanitation in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Turkish_Airlines_Airbus_A321_TC-JTH_(26716697834).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Turkish_Airlines_Airbus_A321_TC-JTH_%2826716697834%29.jpg/220px-Turkish_Airlines_Airbus_A321_TC-JTH_%2826716697834%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Turkish_Airlines_Airbus_A321_TC-JTH_%2826716697834%29.jpg/330px-Turkish_Airlines_Airbus_A321_TC-JTH_%2826716697834%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Turkish_Airlines_Airbus_A321_TC-JTH_%2826716697834%29.jpg/440px-Turkish_Airlines_Airbus_A321_TC-JTH_%2826716697834%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5173" data-file-height="3235"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Turkish_Airlines_Airbus_A321_TC-JTH_(26716697834).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Turkish_Airlines" title="Turkish Airlines">Turkish Airlines</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">flag carrier</a> of Turkey, is the <a href="/wiki/World%27s_largest_airlines#By_number_of_countries_served" class="mw-redirect" title="World's largest airlines">largest carrier in the world by number of countries served</a> as of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-Turkish_Airlines_294-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Turkish_Airlines-294">[292]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[293]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2013 there were 98 <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Turkey" title="List of airports in Turkey">airports in Turkey</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[294]</a></sup> including 22 <a href="/wiki/International_airport" title="International airport">international airports</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[295]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0stanbul_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="İstanbul Airport">İstanbul Airport</a> is planned to be the largest airport in the world, with a capacity to serve 150 million passengers a year.<sup id="cite_ref-dhmi_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dhmi-298">[296]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[297]</a></sup> As well as <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Airlines" title="Turkish Airlines">Turkish Airlines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">flag carrier</a> of Turkey since 1933, <a href="/wiki/List_of_airlines_of_Turkey" title="List of airlines of Turkey">several other airlines operate in the country</a>. </p>
      <p>As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country has a roadway network of 65,623 kilometres (40,776 miles).<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[298]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Turkish_State_Railways" title="Turkish State Railways">Turkish State Railways</a> started building <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_Turkey" title="High-speed rail in Turkey">high-speed rail</a> lines in 2003. The <a href="/wiki/Ankara-Konya_high-speed_railway" class="mw-redirect" title="Ankara-Konya high-speed railway">Ankara-Konya line</a> became operational in 2011, while the <a href="/wiki/Ankara-Istanbul_high-speed_railway" class="mw-redirect" title="Ankara-Istanbul high-speed railway">Ankara-Istanbul line</a> entered service in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-hizlitren.tcdd.gov.tr_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hizlitren.tcdd.gov.tr-301">[299]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Opened in 2013, the <a href="/wiki/Marmaray" title="Marmaray">Marmaray tunnel</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus" class="mw-redirect" title="Bosphorus">Bosphorus</a> connects the railway and <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Metro" title="Istanbul Metro">metro</a> lines of Istanbul's European and Asian sides; while the nearby <a href="/wiki/Eurasia_Tunnel" title="Eurasia Tunnel">Eurasia Tunnel</a> (2016) provides an undersea road connection for motor vehicles.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[300]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:HT80101.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/HT80101.jpg/220px-HT80101.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/HT80101.jpg/330px-HT80101.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/HT80101.jpg/440px-HT80101.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="853"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:HT80101.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/TCDD_HT80000" title="TCDD HT80000">TCDD HT80000</a> <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_Turkey" title="High-speed rail in Turkey">high-speed train</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_State_Railways" title="Turkish State Railways">Turkish State Railways</a><sup id="cite_ref-SiemensVelaroTR_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SiemensVelaroTR-303">[301]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus_Bridge" title="Bosphorus Bridge">Bosphorus Bridge</a> (1973), <a href="/wiki/Fatih_Sultan_Mehmet_Bridge" title="Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge">Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge</a> (1988) and <a href="/wiki/Yavuz_Sultan_Selim_Bridge" title="Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge">Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge</a> (2016) are the three suspension bridges connecting the European and Asian shores of the Bosphorus strait. The <a href="/wiki/Osman_Gazi_Bridge" title="Osman Gazi Bridge">Osman Gazi Bridge</a> (2016) connects the northern and southern shores of the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_%C4%B0zmit" title="Gulf of İzmit">Gulf of İzmit</a>. The <a href="/wiki/%C3%87anakkale_1915_Bridge" title="Çanakkale 1915 Bridge">Çanakkale 1915 Bridge</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">Dardanelles</a> strait, connecting Europe and Asia, will become the <a href="/wiki/List_of_longest_suspension_bridge_spans#Bridges_under_construction" title="List of longest suspension bridge spans">longest suspension bridge in the world</a> upon completion.<sup id="cite_ref-hdn_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hdn-304">[302]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%C3%87anakkale_1915_Bridge_(210128-N-BM428-0068)_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/%C3%87anakkale_1915_Bridge_%28210128-N-BM428-0068%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-%C3%87anakkale_1915_Bridge_%28210128-N-BM428-0068%29_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="87" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/%C3%87anakkale_1915_Bridge_%28210128-N-BM428-0068%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-%C3%87anakkale_1915_Bridge_%28210128-N-BM428-0068%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/%C3%87anakkale_1915_Bridge_%28210128-N-BM428-0068%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-%C3%87anakkale_1915_Bridge_%28210128-N-BM428-0068%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6666" data-file-height="2638"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%C3%87anakkale_1915_Bridge_(210128-N-BM428-0068)_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/%C3%87anakkale_1915_Bridge" title="Çanakkale 1915 Bridge">Çanakkale 1915 Bridge</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">Dardanelles</a> strait, connecting Europe and Asia, will become the <a href="/wiki/List_of_longest_suspension_bridge_spans#Bridges_under_construction" title="List of longest suspension bridge spans">longest suspension bridge in the world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hdn_304-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hdn-304">[302]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Many <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a> pipelines span the country's territory.<sup id="cite_ref-CIAFactbookTurkey_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAFactbookTurkey-305">[303]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan_pipeline" class="mw-redirect" title="Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline">Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline</a>, the second longest <a href="/wiki/Oil_pipeline" class="mw-redirect" title="Oil pipeline">oil pipeline</a> in the world, was inaugurated in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-emreozgur.com_306-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-emreozgur.com-306">[304]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Blue_Stream" title="Blue Stream">Blue Stream</a>, a major trans-<a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> gas pipeline, delivers natural gas from Russia to Turkey. The undersea pipeline, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Stream" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Stream">Turkish Stream</a>, with an annual capacity around 63&nbsp;billion cubic metres (2,200&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/1000000000_(number)" class="mw-redirect" title="1000000000 (number)">billion</a> <a href="/wiki/Cubic_foot" title="Cubic foot">cubic feet</a>), allows Turkey to resell Russian gas to the rest of Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[305]</a></sup> As of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> Turkey consumes 1700 <a href="/wiki/Terawatt" class="mw-redirect" title="Terawatt">terawatt</a> hours (TW/h) of <a href="/wiki/Primary_energy" title="Primary energy">primary energy</a> per year, a little over 20 <a href="/wiki/Megawatt" class="mw-redirect" title="Megawatt">megawatt</a> hours (MW/h) per person, mostly from imported <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuels" class="mw-redirect" title="Fossil fuels">fossil fuels</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[306]</a></sup> Although the <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Energy policy of Turkey">energy policy of Turkey</a> includes reducing fossil-fuel imports, <a href="/wiki/Coal_in_Turkey" title="Coal in Turkey">coal in Turkey</a> is the largest single reason why <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions_by_Turkey" title="Greenhouse gas emissions by Turkey">greenhouse gas emissions by Turkey</a> amount to 1% of the global total. <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_Turkey" title="Renewable energy in Turkey">Renewable energy in Turkey</a> is being increased and <a href="/wiki/Akkuyu_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Akkuyu Nuclear Power Plant">Akkuyu Nuclear Power Plant</a> is being built on the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean</a> coast: but despite <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Turkey" title="Electricity sector in Turkey">national electricity generation</a> overcapacity <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel_subsidies" class="mw-redirect" title="Fossil fuel subsidies">fossil fuels are still subsidized</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[307]</a></sup> Turkey has the fifth-highest direct utilisation and capacity of <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_power_in_Turkey" title="Geothermal power in Turkey">geothermal power</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-look_310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-look-310">[308]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Turkey" title="Science and technology in Turkey">Science and technology in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Scientific_and_Technological_Research_Council_of_Turkey" title="Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey">TÜBİTAK</a> is the leading agency for developing <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Turkey" title="Science and technology in Turkey">science, technology and innovation policies in Turkey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[309]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Turkish Academy of Sciences">TÜBA</a> is an autonomous scholarly society acting to promote scientific activities in Turkey.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[310]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/TAEK" class="mw-redirect" title="TAEK">TAEK</a> is the official <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_technology" title="Nuclear technology">nuclear energy</a> institution of Turkey. Its objectives include academic research in nuclear energy, and the development and implementation of peaceful nuclear tools.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[311]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:TaiIDEF2015_(8).JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG/220px-TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG/330px-TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG/440px-TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3696" data-file-height="2448"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:TaiIDEF2015_(8).JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrk-1" title="Göktürk-1">Göktürk-1</a>, <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrk-2" title="Göktürk-2">Göktürk-2</a> and <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrk-3" title="Göktürk-3">Göktürk-3</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Earth_observation_satellite" title="Earth observation satellite">Earth observation satellites</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Defense_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of National Defense (Turkey)">Turkish Ministry of National Defense</a>, while state-owned <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrksat_(company)" title="Türksat (company)">Türksat</a> operates the <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrksat_(satellite)" title="Türksat (satellite)">Türksat series</a> of <a href="/wiki/Communications_satellite" title="Communications satellite">communications satellites</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Turkish government companies for <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> in <a href="/wiki/Military_technology" title="Military technology">military technologies</a> include <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Aerospace_Industries" title="Turkish Aerospace Industries">Turkish Aerospace Industries</a>, <a href="/wiki/ASELSAN" class="mw-redirect" title="ASELSAN">ASELSAN</a>, <a href="/wiki/HAVELSAN" title="HAVELSAN">HAVELSAN</a>, <a href="/wiki/ROKETSAN" title="ROKETSAN">ROKETSAN</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mechanical_and_Chemical_Industry_Corporation" title="Mechanical and Chemical Industry Corporation">MKE</a>, among others. <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Satellite_Assembly,_Integration_and_Test_Center" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Satellite Assembly, Integration and Test Center">Turkish Satellite Assembly, Integration and Test Center</a> (UMET) is a spacecraft production and testing facility owned by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Defence_(Turkey)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of National Defence (Turkey)">Ministry of National Defence</a> and operated by the Turkish Aerospace Industries (TAI). </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Space_Launch_System_(Turkey)" title="Space Launch System (Turkey)">Turkish Space Launch System</a> (UFS) is a project to develop the satellite launch capability of Turkey. It consists of the construction of a <a href="/wiki/Spaceport" title="Spaceport">spaceport</a>, the development of <a href="/wiki/Satellite_launch_vehicle" class="mw-redirect" title="Satellite launch vehicle">satellite launch vehicles</a> as well as the establishment of remote earth stations.<sup id="cite_ref-ssm1_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ssm1-314">[312]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dn1_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dn1-315">[313]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dn2_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dn2-316">[314]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrksat_(company)" title="Türksat (company)">Türksat</a> is the sole <a href="/wiki/Communications_satellite" title="Communications satellite">communications satellite</a> operator in Turkey and has launched the <a href="/wiki/Turksat_(satellite)" class="mw-redirect" title="Turksat (satellite)">Türksat series of satellites</a> into orbit. <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrk-1" title="Göktürk-1">Göktürk-1</a>, <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrk-2" title="Göktürk-2">Göktürk-2</a> and <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrk-3" title="Göktürk-3">Göktürk-3</a> are Turkey's <a href="/wiki/Earth_observation_satellite" title="Earth observation satellite">Earth observation satellites</a> for <a href="/wiki/Reconnaissance" title="Reconnaissance">reconnaissance</a>, operated by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Defense_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of National Defense (Turkey)">Turkish Ministry of National Defense</a>. <a href="/wiki/BILSAT-1" title="BILSAT-1">BILSAT-1</a> and <a href="/wiki/RASAT" title="RASAT">RASAT</a> are the scientific Earth observation satellites operated by the <a href="/wiki/T%C3%9CB%C4%B0TAK_Space_Technologies_Research_Institute" title="TÜBİTAK Space Technologies Research Institute">TÜBİTAK Space Technologies Research Institute</a>. </p>
      <p>In 2015, <a href="/wiki/Aziz_Sancar" title="Aziz Sancar">Aziz Sancar</a>, a Turkish professor at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_North_Carolina" title="University of North Carolina">University of North Carolina</a>, won the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Chemistry_Prize" class="mw-redirect" title="Nobel Chemistry Prize">Nobel Chemistry Prize</a> along with <a href="/wiki/Tomas_Lindahl" title="Tomas Lindahl">Tomas Lindahl</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paul_Modrich" class="mw-redirect" title="Paul Modrich">Paul Modrich</a>, for their work on how cells repair damaged DNA.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[315]</a></sup> Other Turkish scientists include physician <a href="/wiki/Hulusi_Beh%C3%A7et" title="Hulusi Behçet">Hulusi Behçet</a> who discovered <a href="/wiki/Beh%C3%A7et%27s_disease" title="Behçet's disease">Behçet's disease</a> and mathematician <a href="/wiki/Cahit_Arf" title="Cahit Arf">Cahit Arf</a> who defined the <a href="/wiki/Arf_invariant" title="Arf invariant">Arf invariant</a>. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Turkey" title="Demographics of Turkey">Demographics of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turkish people</a>
      </div>

      </table> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kurdistan_of_Turkey_(CIA).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png/170px-Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png" decoding="async" width="170" height="83" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png/255px-Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png/340px-Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="977"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kurdistan_of_Turkey_(CIA).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/CIA" class="mw-redirect" title="CIA">CIA</a> map of areas with a Kurdish majority<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[317]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the <i>Address-Based Population Recording System</i> of Turkey, the country's population was 74.7&nbsp;million people in 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-2011stat_320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011stat-320">[318]</a></sup> nearly three-quarters of whom lived in <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">towns and cities</a>. According to the 2011 estimate, the population is increasing by 1.35 percent each year. Turkey has an average population density of 97 people per km². People within the 15–64 <a href="/wiki/Age_group" class="mw-redirect" title="Age group">age group</a> constitute 67.4 percent of the total population; the 0–14 age group corresponds to 25.3 percent; while senior citizens aged 65 years or older make up 7.3 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[319]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Article 66 of the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Constitution">Turkish Constitution</a> defines a "Turk" as "anyone who is bound to the Turkish state through the bond of citizenship"; therefore, the legal use of the term "Turkish" as a <a href="/wiki/Citizenship" title="Citizenship">citizen</a> of Turkey is different from the <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_group" title="Ethnic group">ethnic</a> definition.<sup id="cite_ref-:02_322-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-322">[320]</a></sup> However approximately 70 to 80 percent of the country's citizens are ethnic Turks.<sup id="cite_ref-konda2_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-konda2-323">[321]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cia_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-4">[4]</a></sup> It is estimated that there are at least 47 ethnic groups represented in Turkey.<sup id="cite_ref-mutlu_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mutlu-324">[322]</a></sup> Reliable data on the ethnic mix of the population is not available, because Turkish census figures do not include statistics on ethnicity.<sup id="cite_ref-Turkey_Ethnic_groups_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Turkey_Ethnic_groups-325">[323]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2019.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2019.png/170px-Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2019.png" decoding="async" width="170" height="73" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2019.png/255px-Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2019.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2019.png/340px-Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2019.png 2x" data-file-width="1579" data-file-height="677"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2019.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Turkey total fertility rate by province (2019)<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[324]</a></sup> 
         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style>
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#ffff00; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;3-4
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#0cff00; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;2-3
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#24e0d9; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;1.5-2
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#3aafe0; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;1-1.5
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Kurds_in_Turkey" title="Kurds in Turkey">Kurds</a> are the largest non-Turkish ethnicity at anywhere from 12-25 per cent of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[325]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-kirisci_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kirisci-328">[326]</a></sup> The exact figure remains a subject of dispute; according to Servet Mutlu, "more often than not, these estimates reflect pro-Kurdish or pro-Turkish sympathies and attitudes rather than scientific facts or erudition".<sup id="cite_ref-mutlu_324-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mutlu-324">[322]</a></sup> Mutlu's 1990 study estimated Kurds made up around 12 per cent of the population, while <a href="/wiki/Mehrdad_Izady" title="Mehrdad Izady">Mehrdad Izady</a> placed the figure around 25 per cent.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[327]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurds</a> make up a majority in the provinces of <a href="/wiki/A%C4%9Fr%C4%B1_Province" title="Ağrı Province">Ağrı</a>, <a href="/wiki/Batman_Province" title="Batman Province">Batman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bing%C3%B6l_Province" title="Bingöl Province">Bingöl</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bitlis_Province" title="Bitlis Province">Bitlis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diyarbak%C4%B1r_Province" title="Diyarbakır Province">Diyarbakır</a>, <a href="/wiki/El%C3%A2z%C4%B1%C4%9F_Province" class="mw-redirect" title="Elâzığ Province">Elâzığ</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hakkari_Province" class="mw-redirect" title="Hakkari Province">Hakkari</a>, <a href="/wiki/I%C4%9Fd%C4%B1r_Province" title="Iğdır Province">Iğdır</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mardin_Province" title="Mardin Province">Mardin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mu%C5%9F_Province" title="Muş Province">Muş</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siirt_Province" title="Siirt Province">Siirt</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%9E%C4%B1rnak_Province" title="Şırnak Province">Şırnak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tunceli_Province" title="Tunceli Province">Tunceli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Van_Province" title="Van Province">Van</a>; a near majority in <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Eanl%C4%B1urfa_Province" title="Şanlıurfa Province">Şanlıurfa Province</a> (47%); and a large minority in <a href="/wiki/Kars_Province" title="Kars Province">Kars Province</a> (20%).<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[328]</a></sup> In addition, due to internal migration, <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_diaspora" class="mw-redirect" title="Kurdish diaspora">Kurdish diaspora</a> communities exist in all of the major cities in central and western Turkey. In Istanbul, there are an estimated three million Kurds, making it the city with the largest Kurdish population in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Nachmani2003_331-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nachmani2003-331">[329]</a></sup> Non-Kurdish minorities are believed to make up an estimated 7–12 percent of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_4-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-4">[4]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The three "<a href="/wiki/Millet_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Millet (Ottoman Empire)">Non-Muslim</a>" minority groups recognised in the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a> were <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_Turkey" title="Armenians in Turkey">Armenians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greeks_in_Turkey" title="Greeks in Turkey">Greeks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jews_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Jews in Turkey">Jews</a>. Other ethnic groups include <a href="/wiki/Albanians_in_Turkey" title="Albanians in Turkey">Albanians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_Turkey" title="Arabs in Turkey">Arabs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Assyrians_in_Turkey" title="Assyrians in Turkey">Assyrians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks_in_Turkey" title="Bosniaks in Turkey">Bosniaks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Circassians_in_Turkey" title="Circassians in Turkey">Circassians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgians_in_Turkey" title="Georgians in Turkey">Georgians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laz_people" title="Laz people">Laz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pomaks" title="Pomaks">Pomaks</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Roma</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_4-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-4">[4]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Roopnarine2015_332-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roopnarine2015-332">[330]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MedinaHepner2013_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MedinaHepner2013-333">[331]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[332]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[333]</a></sup> Turkey is also home to a Muslim community of <a href="/wiki/Megleno-Romanians" title="Megleno-Romanians">Megleno-Romanians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-megl_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-megl-336">[334]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Before the start of the <a href="/wiki/Syrian_civil_war" title="Syrian civil war">Syrian civil war</a> in 2011, the estimated number of <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_Turkey" title="Arabs in Turkey">Arabs in Turkey</a> varied from 1 million to more than 2 million.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[335]</a></sup> As of April 2020, there are 3.6 million <a href="/wiki/Refugees_of_the_Syrian_Civil_War_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Refugees of the Syrian Civil War in Turkey">Syrian refugees</a> in Turkey, who are mostly Arabs but also include <a href="/wiki/Syrian_Kurds" class="mw-redirect" title="Syrian Kurds">Syrian Kurds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syrian_Turkmen" title="Syrian Turkmen">Syrian Turkmen</a>, and other <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Syria" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethnic groups of Syria">ethnic groups of Syria</a>. The vast majority of these are living in Turkey with temporary residence permits. The Turkish government has granted Turkish citizenship to refugees who have joined the <a href="/wiki/Syrian_National_Army" title="Syrian National Army">Syrian National Army</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-unhcr-syrian-refugees_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unhcr-syrian-refugees-338">[336]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[337]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[338]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="10" class="navbox-title">
          <div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">
           &nbsp;
          </div><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r992953826">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}.mw-parser-output .infobox .navbar{font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .navbox .navbar{display:block;font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .navbox-title .navbar{float:left;text-align:left;margin-right:0.5em}</style>
          <div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini" style="float: left;height:2.6em;">
           <ul>
            <li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Largest_cities_in_Turkey" title="Template:Largest cities in Turkey"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li>

            <li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_cities_in_Turkey&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li>
           </ul>
          </div> 
          <div style="height:2.6em;line-height:1.3em;">
           <span style="font-size:110%;">Largest cities or towns in Turkey</span>
           <br>
           <div style="display:inline;font-weight:normal;">
            <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Statistical_Institute" title="Turkish Statistical Institute">TÜİK</a>'s address-based calculation from December 2017.
           </div>
          </div> </th>
        </tr>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Immigration">Immigration</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Turkey" title="Immigration to Turkey">Immigration to Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Turkey%27s_migrant_crisis" title="Turkey's migrant crisis">Turkey's migrant crisis</a>
      </div>
