      <p><a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Turkey" title="Immigration to Turkey">Immigration to Turkey</a> is the process by which people <a href="/wiki/Human_migration" title="Human migration">migrate</a> to Turkey to reside in the country. <a href="/wiki/Turkey%27s_migrant_crisis" title="Turkey's migrant crisis">Turkey's migrant crisis</a> created after an estimated 2.5 percent of the population are <a href="/wiki/Human_migration" title="Human migration">international migrants</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-esa.un.org_341-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-esa.un.org-341">[339]</a></sup> Turkey hosts the largest number of <a href="/wiki/Refugee" title="Refugee">refugees</a> in the world, including 3.6 million <a href="/wiki/Refugees_of_the_Syrian_Civil_War_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Refugees of the Syrian Civil War in Turkey">Syrian refugees</a>, as of April 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-unhcr-syrian-refugees_338-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unhcr-syrian-refugees-338">[336]</a></sup> As part of <a href="/wiki/Turkey%27s_migrant_crisis" title="Turkey's migrant crisis">Turkey's migrant crisis</a>, according to <a href="/wiki/UNHCR" class="mw-redirect" title="UNHCR">UNHCR</a>, in 2018 Turkey was hosting 63.4% of all the refugees in the world, that is 3,564,919 registered refugees from Africa and the Middle East in total.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[340]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Turkey" title="Languages of Turkey">Languages of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a> is <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>, which is the most widely spoken <a href="/wiki/Turkic_languages" title="Turkic languages">Turkic language</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-katzner_343-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-katzner-343">[341]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-minorityrights.org_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-minorityrights.org-344">[342]</a></sup> It is spoken by 85.54 percent of the population as a <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">first language</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-milliyet-languages_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milliyet-languages-345">[343]</a></sup> 11.97 percent of the population speaks the <a href="/wiki/Kurmanji" title="Kurmanji">Kurmanji</a> dialect of <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_languages" title="Kurdish languages">Kurdish</a> as their mother tongue.<sup id="cite_ref-milliyet-languages_345-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milliyet-languages-345">[343]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zaza_language" title="Zaza language">Zaza</a> are the mother tongues of 2.39 percent of the population, and several other languages are the mother tongues of smaller parts of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-milliyet-languages_345-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milliyet-languages-345">[343]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Endangered_language" title="Endangered language">Endangered</a> <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Turkey" title="Languages of Turkey">languages in Turkey</a> include <a href="/wiki/Abaza_language" title="Abaza language">Abaza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abkhaz_language" title="Abkhaz language">Abkhaz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adyghe_language" title="Adyghe language">Adyghe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cappadocian_Greek" title="Cappadocian Greek">Cappadocian Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gagauz_language" title="Gagauz language">Gagauz</a>, <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A9rtevin" class="mw-redirect" title="Hértevin">Hértevin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Homshetsma" class="mw-redirect" title="Homshetsma">Homshetsma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kabard-Cherkes" class="mw-redirect" title="Kabard-Cherkes">Kabard-Cherkes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judaeo-Spanish" title="Judaeo-Spanish">Ladino (Judesmo)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laz_language" title="Laz language">Laz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mlahso" class="mw-redirect" title="Mlahso">Mlahso</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Greek" title="Pontic Greek">Pontic Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romani_language" title="Romani language">Romani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suret" class="mw-redirect" title="Suret">Suret</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turoyo" class="mw-redirect" title="Turoyo">Turoyo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ubykh_language" title="Ubykh language">Ubykh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Western_Armenian" title="Western Armenian">Western Armenian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-www.unesco.org_index_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www.unesco.org_index-346">[344]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Megleno-Romanian_language" title="Megleno-Romanian language">Megleno-Romanian</a> is also spoken.<sup id="cite_ref-megl_336-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-megl-336">[334]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Turkey" title="Religion in Turkey">Religion in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">Secularism in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:EAA_Sancaklar_Mosque.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/EAA_Sancaklar_Mosque.jpg/220px-EAA_Sancaklar_Mosque.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="106" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/EAA_Sancaklar_Mosque.jpg/330px-EAA_Sancaklar_Mosque.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/EAA_Sancaklar_Mosque.jpg/440px-EAA_Sancaklar_Mosque.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="1451"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:EAA_Sancaklar_Mosque.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Sancaklar Mosque is a contemporary mosque in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Turkey is a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a> with no official <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Constitution">Turkish Constitution</a> provides for <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a> and conscience.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[345]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[346]</a></sup> A 2016 survey by <a href="/wiki/Ipsos" title="Ipsos">Ipsos</a>, interviewing 17,180 adults across 22 countries, found that <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> was the dominant religion in Turkey, adhered to by 82% of the total population; religiously unaffiliated people comprised 13% of the population, while 2% were <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ipsos2017_349-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ipsos2017-349">[347]</a></sup> According to religiosity poll conducted in Turkey in 2019 by OPTİMAR, 89.5% of the population identifies as Muslim, 4.5% believed in God but did not belong to an organized religion, 2.7% were <a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">agnostic</a>, 1.7% were <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheist</a>, and 1.7% did not answer.<sup id="cite_ref-hurriyetreligion_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hurriyetreligion-350">[348]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-t24religion_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-t24religion-351">[349]</a></sup> Another poll conducted by Gezici Araştırma in 2020 interviewed 1,062 people in 12 provinces and found that 28.5% of the <a href="/wiki/Generation_Z" title="Generation Z">Generation Z</a> in Turkey identify as <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Turkey" title="Irreligion in Turkey">irreligious</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[350]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[351]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" class="mw-redirect" title="CIA World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a></i> reports that Islam is the religion of 99.8% of the population, with <a href="/wiki/Sunni" class="mw-redirect" title="Sunni">Sunni</a> Muslims as the largest sect, while 0.2% are Christians and Jews.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[352]</a></sup> However, there are no official governmental statistics specifying the religious beliefs of the Turkish people, nor is religious data recorded in the country's census.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[353]</a></sup> Academics suggest the <a href="/wiki/Alevi" class="mw-redirect" title="Alevi">Alevi</a> population may be from 15 to 20 million, while the Alevi-Bektaşi Federation states that there are around 25&nbsp;million.<sup id="cite_ref-usstate_356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-usstate-356">[354]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-refworld.org1_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-refworld.org1-357">[355]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Aksiyon" title="Aksiyon">Aksiyon</a> magazine, the number of <a href="/wiki/Twelver" title="Twelver">Twelver</a> <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shias</a> (excluding Alevis) is three million (4.2%).<sup id="cite_ref-caferi_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-caferi-358">[356]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:St._Anthony_of_Padua_Church_in_Istanbul_06.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/St._Anthony_of_Padua_Church_in_Istanbul_06.JPG/220px-St._Anthony_of_Padua_Church_in_Istanbul_06.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/St._Anthony_of_Padua_Church_in_Istanbul_06.JPG/330px-St._Anthony_of_Padua_Church_in_Istanbul_06.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/St._Anthony_of_Padua_Church_in_Istanbul_06.JPG/440px-St._Anthony_of_Padua_Church_in_Istanbul_06.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:St._Anthony_of_Padua_Church_in_Istanbul_06.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Church_of_St._Anthony_of_Padua,_Istanbul" title="Church of St. Anthony of Padua, Istanbul">Church of St. Anthony of Padua</a> on <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0stiklal_Avenue" title="İstiklal Avenue">İstiklal Avenue</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Beyo%C4%9Flu" title="Beyoğlu">Beyoğlu</a> district of <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>. There are 234 active churches in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-heper2018_359-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-heper2018-359">[357]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> has a long history in present-day Turkey, which is the birthplace of numerous Christian <a href="/wiki/Twelve_apostles" class="mw-redirect" title="Twelve apostles">apostles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint" title="Saint">saints</a>. <a href="/wiki/Antioch" title="Antioch">Antioch</a> (<a href="/wiki/Antakya" title="Antakya">Antakya</a>) is regarded by tradition as the spot where the <a href="/wiki/Gospels" class="mw-redirect" title="Gospels">Gospels</a> were written, and where the followers of <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a> were called Christians for the first time. The percentage of Christians in Turkey fell from 17.5% (three million followers) in a population of 16&nbsp;million to 2.5% percent in the early 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[358]</a></sup> mainly as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide" class="mw-redirect" title="Armenian Genocide">Armenian Genocide</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_and_Turkey" title="Population exchange between Greece and Turkey">population exchange between Greece and Turkey</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[359]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Christian_emigration" title="Christian emigration">emigration of Christians</a> that began in the late 19th century and gained pace in the first quarter of the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[360]</a></sup> Today, there are more than 120,000-320,000 people of various <a href="/wiki/Christian_denominations" class="mw-redirect" title="Christian denominations">Christian denominations</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Pew_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pew-363">[361]</a></sup> representing less than 0.2% of Turkey's population,<sup id="cite_ref-cia-rel_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-rel-364">[362]</a></sup> including an estimated 80,000 <a href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox" class="mw-redirect" title="Oriental Orthodox">Oriental Orthodox</a>, 35,000 <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Roman Catholics</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-catho_365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-catho-365">[363]</a></sup> 18,000 <a href="/wiki/Antiochian_Greeks" class="mw-redirect" title="Antiochian Greeks">Antiochian Greeks</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[364]</a></sup> 5,000 <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Church" title="Greek Orthodox Church">Greek Orthodox</a> and smaller numbers of <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestants</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-christiancentury.org_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-christiancentury.org-367">[365]</a></sup> Currently there are 236 churches open for worship in Turkey.<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">[366]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Modern-day Turkey continues to have a small Jewish population;<sup id="cite_ref-science.co.il_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-science.co.il-369">[367]</a></sup> with around 26,000 <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Turkey" title="History of the Jews in Turkey">Jews</a>, the vast majority of whom are Sephardi.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[368]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In a mid-2010s poll, 2.9% of Turkish respondents identified as atheists.<sup id="cite_ref-human.nl_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-human.nl-371">[369]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ateizm_Derne%C4%9Fi" title="Ateizm Derneği">Association of Atheism</a>, the first official atheist organisation in the Balkans and the Middle East, was founded in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-blogs.lse.ac.uk1_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-blogs.lse.ac.uk1-372">[370]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-turkishatheist.net1_373-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-turkishatheist.net1-373">[371]</a></sup> Some religious and secular officials have claimed that <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Deism" title="Deism">deism</a> are growing among Turkish people.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[372]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[373]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[374]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[375]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Turkey" title="Education in Turkey">Education in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_high_schools_in_Turkey" title="List of high schools in Turkey">List of high schools in Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Turkey" title="List of universities in Turkey">List of universities in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Main_entrance_gate_of_Istanbul_University.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Main_entrance_gate_of_Istanbul_University.jpg/220px-Main_entrance_gate_of_Istanbul_University.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Main_entrance_gate_of_Istanbul_University.jpg/330px-Main_entrance_gate_of_Istanbul_University.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Main_entrance_gate_of_Istanbul_University.jpg/440px-Main_entrance_gate_of_Istanbul_University.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5312" data-file-height="2988"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Main_entrance_gate_of_Istanbul_University.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Istanbul_University" title="Istanbul University">Istanbul University</a> was founded in 1453 as a <i><a href="/wiki/Institute_of_technology" title="Institute of technology">Darülfünûn</a></i>. On 1 August 1933 it was reorganised and became the Republic's first university.<sup id="cite_ref-istanbuluniversity_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-istanbuluniversity-378">[376]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Education_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of National Education (Turkey)">Ministry of National Education</a> is responsible for pre-tertiary education.<sup id="cite_ref-wesed_379-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wesed-379">[377]</a></sup> This is compulsory and lasts twelve years: four years each of primary school, middle school and high school.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt-peg_380-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-peg-380">[378]</a></sup> Basic education in Turkey is said to lag behind other OECD countries, with significant differences between high and low performers.<sup id="cite_ref-WBedu_381-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WBedu-381">[379]</a></sup> Access to high-quality school heavily depends on the performance in the secondary school entrance exams, to the point that some students begin taking private tutoring classes when they are ten years old.<sup id="cite_ref-WBedu_381-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WBedu-381">[379]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As of 2017, there are 190 <a href="/wiki/Universities_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Universities in Turkey">universities in Turkey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[380]</a></sup> Except for the Open Education Faculties (AÖF) at <a href="/wiki/Anadolu_University" title="Anadolu University">Anadolu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_University" title="Istanbul University">Istanbul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk_University" title="Atatürk University">Atatürk University</a>; entrance is regulated by the national <a href="/wiki/Student_Selection_and_Placement_System" title="Student Selection and Placement System">Student Selection and Placement System</a> (ÖSYS) examination, after which high school graduates are assigned to universities according to their performance.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[381]</a></sup> According to the 2012–2013 <a href="/wiki/Times_Higher_Education_World_University_Rankings" title="Times Higher Education World University Rankings">Times Higher Education World University Rankings</a>, the top university in Turkey is <a href="/wiki/Middle_East_Technical_University" title="Middle East Technical University">Middle East Technical University</a>, followed by <a href="/wiki/Bilkent_University" title="Bilkent University">Bilkent University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ko%C3%A7_University" title="Koç University">Koç University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Technical_University" title="Istanbul Technical University">Istanbul Technical University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_University" title="Boğaziçi University">Boğaziçi University</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-therank_384-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-therank-384">[382]</a></sup> All state and private universities are under the control of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Higher_Education_(Turkey)" title="Council of Higher Education (Turkey)">Higher Education Board</a> (YÖK), whose head is appointed by the President of Turkey; and since 2016 the President directly appoints all rectors of all state and private universities.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[383]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Turkey" title="Health care in Turkey">Health care in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_hospitals_in_Turkey" title="List of hospitals in Turkey">List of hospitals in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_(1).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_%281%29.jpg/220px-Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_%281%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="144" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_%281%29.jpg/330px-Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_%281%29.jpg/440px-Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_%281%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4898" data-file-height="3216"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_(1).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Acıbadem Hospital in Altunizade neighborhood of Üsküdar, <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0stanbul" class="mw-redirect" title="İstanbul">İstanbul</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of Health (Turkey)">Ministry of Health</a> has run a universal public healthcare system since 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-njm_386-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-njm-386">[384]</a></sup> Known as Universal Health Insurance (<i lang="tr" title="Turkish-language text">Genel Sağlık Sigortası</i>), it is funded by a tax surcharge on employers, currently at 5%.<sup id="cite_ref-njm_386-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-njm-386">[384]</a></sup> Public-sector funding covers approximately 75.2% of health expenditures.<sup id="cite_ref-njm_386-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-njm-386">[384]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Despite the universal health care, total expenditure on health as a share of GDP in 2018 was the lowest among OECD countries at 6.3% of GDP, compared to the OECD average of 9.3%.<sup id="cite_ref-njm_386-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-njm-386">[384]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Average life expectancy is 78.6 years (75.9 for males and 81.3 for females), compared with the EU average of 81 years.<sup id="cite_ref-njm_386-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-njm-386">[384]</a></sup> Turkey has one of the highest rates of <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">obesity</a> in the world, with nearly one third (29.5%) of its adult population having a <a href="/wiki/Body_mass_index" title="Body mass index">body mass index</a> (BMI) value that is 30 or above.<sup id="cite_ref-WHO_Mean_Body_Mass_Index_BMI_387-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WHO_Mean_Body_Mass_Index_BMI-387">[385]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Air_pollution_in_Turkey" title="Air pollution in Turkey">Air pollution in Turkey</a> is a major cause of early death.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[386]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Turkey" title="Culture of Turkey">Culture of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Arts_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Arts in Turkey">Arts in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_folklore" title="Turkish folklore">Turkish folklore</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Festivals_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Festivals in Turkey">Festivals in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Whirlingdervishes.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Whirlingdervishes.JPG/220px-Whirlingdervishes.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="156" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Whirlingdervishes.JPG/330px-Whirlingdervishes.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Whirlingdervishes.JPG/440px-Whirlingdervishes.JPG 2x" data-file-width="707" data-file-height="500"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Whirlingdervishes.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Whirling Dervishes of the <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">Sufi</a> <a href="/wiki/Mevlevi_Order" title="Mevlevi Order">Mevlevi Order</a>, founded by the followers of the 13th-century Sufi <a href="/wiki/Mysticism" title="Mysticism">mystic</a> and poet <a href="/wiki/Rumi" title="Rumi">Rumi</a> in <a href="/wiki/Konya" title="Konya">Konya</a>, during a <a href="/wiki/Sema" class="mw-redirect" title="Sema">Sema</a>. The ceremony is one of the 11 elements of Turkey on the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-unesco1_389-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unesco1-389">[387]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Turkey has a very diverse culture that is a blend of various elements of the <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Culture of the Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> (which was itself a continuation of both <a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman" class="mw-redirect" title="Greco-Roman">Greco-Roman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_culture" title="Islamic culture">Islamic</a> cultures) and <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western culture</a> and traditions, which started with the <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Westernisation of the Ottoman Empire</a> and still continues today.<sup id="cite_ref-TR_culture_390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TR_culture-390">[388]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[389]</a></sup> This mix originally began as a result of the encounter of Turks and their culture with those of the peoples who were in their path during <a href="/wiki/Turkic_migration" title="Turkic migration">their migration</a> from Central Asia to the West.<sup id="cite_ref-TR_culture_390-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TR_culture-390">[388]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[390]</a></sup> Turkish culture is a product of efforts to be a "modern" Western state, while maintaining traditional religious and historical values.<sup id="cite_ref-TR_culture_390-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TR_culture-390">[388]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">Visual arts</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_painting" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish painting">Turkish painting</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0znik_pottery" class="mw-redirect" title="İznik pottery">İznik pottery</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_carpet" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish carpet">Turkish carpet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_miniature" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish miniature">Turkish miniature</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_illumination" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish illumination">Turkish illumination</a>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/List_of_Turkish_painters" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Turkish painters">Turkish painting</a>, in the Western sense, developed actively starting from the mid 19th century. The first painting lessons were scheduled at what is now the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Technical_University" title="Istanbul Technical University">Istanbul Technical University</a> (then the <i>Imperial Military Engineering School</i>) in 1793, mostly for technical purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-HarriOhta1999_393-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HarriOhta1999-393">[391]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the late 19th century, human figure in the Western sense was being established in Turkish painting, especially with <a href="/wiki/Osman_Hamdi_Bey" title="Osman Hamdi Bey">Osman Hamdi Bey</a> (1842–1910). Impressionism, among the contemporary trends, appeared later on with <a href="/wiki/Halil_Pasha_(painter)" title="Halil Pasha (painter)">Halil Pasha</a> (c.1857–1939). Other important Turkish painters in the 19th century were <a href="/wiki/Ferik_%C4%B0brahim_Pasha" title="Ferik İbrahim Pasha">Ferik İbrahim Paşa</a> (1815–1891), <a href="/wiki/Osman_Nuri_Pasha_(painter)" title="Osman Nuri Pasha (painter)">Osman Nuri Paşa</a> (c.1839–1906), <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Eeker_Ahmet_Pa%C5%9Fa" class="mw-redirect" title="Şeker Ahmet Paşa">Şeker Ahmet Paşa</a> (1841–1907), and <a href="/wiki/Hoca_Ali_Riza" class="mw-redirect" title="Hoca Ali Riza">Hoca Ali Riza</a> (1864–1939). </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:300px;max-width:300px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:166px;max-width:166px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/164px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" decoding="async" width="164" height="239" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/246px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/328px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2419" data-file-height="3527"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:130px;max-width:130px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/128px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" decoding="async" width="128" height="239" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/192px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/256px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" data-file-width="9492" data-file-height="17758"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          <i>Two Musician Girls</i> (left) and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tortoise_Trainer" title="The Tortoise Trainer">The Tortoise Trainer</a></i> (right) by <a href="/wiki/Osman_Hamdi_Bey" title="Osman Hamdi Bey">Osman Hamdi Bey</a>, at the <a href="/wiki/Pera_Museum" title="Pera Museum">Pera Museum</a>.
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The young Turkish artists sent to Europe in 1926 came back inspired by contemporary trends such as Fauvism, Cubism and even Expressionism, still very influential in Europe. The later "Group D" of artists led by <a href="/wiki/Abidin_Dino" title="Abidin Dino">Abidin Dino</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cemal_Tollu" title="Cemal Tollu">Cemal Tollu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fikret_Mualla" class="mw-redirect" title="Fikret Mualla">Fikret Mualla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Princess_Fahrelnissa_Zeid" title="Princess Fahrelnissa Zeid">Fahrünnisa Zeid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bedri_Rahmi_Eyuboglu" class="mw-redirect" title="Bedri Rahmi Eyuboglu">Bedri Rahmi Eyüboğlu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adnan_Coker" title="Adnan Coker">Adnan Çoker</a> and <a href="/wiki/Burhan_Do%C4%9Fan%C3%A7ay" title="Burhan Doğançay">Burhan Doğançay</a> introduced some trends that had lasted in the West for more than three decades. Other important movements in Turkish painting were the "Yeniler Grubu" (The Newcomers Group) of the late 1930s; the "On'lar Grubu" (Group of Ten) of the 1940s; the "Yeni Dal Grubu" (New Branch Group) of the 1950s; and the "Siyah Kalem Grubu" (Black Pen Group) of the 1960s.<sup id="cite_ref-turkresmi.com_394-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-turkresmi.com-394">[392]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Turkish_carpet" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish carpet">Carpet weaving</a> is a traditional art from pre-Islamic times. During its long history, the art and craft of the woven carpet has integrated different cultural traditions. Traces of Byzantine design can be detected; <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic peoples</a> migrating from Central Asia, as well as Armenian people, Caucasian and Kurdish tribes either living in, or migrating to Anatolia, brought with them their traditional designs. The arrival of Islam and the development of <a href="/wiki/Islamic_art" title="Islamic art">Islamic art</a> also influenced Turkish carpet design. The history of its designs, motifs and ornaments thus reflects the political and ethnic history and diversity of <a href="/wiki/Asia_minor" class="mw-redirect" title="Asia minor">Asia minor</a>. However, scientific attempts were unsuccessful, as yet, to attribute a particular design to a specific ethnic, regional, or even nomadic versus village tradition.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[393]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri,_Turkey,_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri%2C_Turkey%2C_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/220px-Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri%2C_Turkey%2C_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="149" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri%2C_Turkey%2C_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/330px-Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri%2C_Turkey%2C_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri%2C_Turkey%2C_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/440px-Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri%2C_Turkey%2C_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4001" data-file-height="2704"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri,_Turkey,_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ottoman_miniature" title="Ottoman miniature">Ottoman miniature</a> was a Turkish art form that thrived during the Ottoman period, with its origins in the Persian miniature tradition, and with strong Chinese artistic influences.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Ottoman_miniature" title="Ottoman miniature">Ottoman miniature</a> is linked to the Persian miniature tradition, as well as strong Chinese artistic influences. The words <i>tasvir</i> or <i>nakış</i> were used to define the art of miniature painting in Ottoman Turkish. The studios the artists worked in were called <i>nakkaşhane</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-miniature1_396-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miniature1-396">[394]</a></sup> The miniatures were usually not signed, perhaps because of the rejection of individualism, but also because the works were not created entirely by one person; the head painter designed the composition of the scene, and his apprentices drew the contours (which were called <i>tahrir</i>) with black or colored ink and then painted the miniature without creating an illusion of depth. The head painter, and much more often the scribe of the text, were indeed named and depicted in some of the manuscripts. The understanding of perspective was different from that of the nearby European Renaissance painting tradition, and the scene depicted often included different time periods and spaces in one picture. They followed closely the context of the book they were included in, more illustrations than standalone works of art.<sup id="cite_ref-turkishculture.org2_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-turkishculture.org2-397">[395]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The earliest examples of <a href="/wiki/Turkish_paper_marbling" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish paper marbling">Turkish paper marbling</a>, called <i><a href="/wiki/Ebru" title="Ebru">ebru</a></i> in Turkish, are said to be a copy of the <i>Hâlnâme</i> by the poet Arifî. The text of this manuscript was rendered in a delicate cut paper découpage calligraphy by Mehmed bin Gazanfer and completed in 1540, and features many marbled and decorative paper borders. One early master by the <a href="/wiki/Pseudonym" title="Pseudonym">pseudonym</a> of <i>Şebek</i> is mentioned posthumously in the earliest Ottoman text on the art known as the <i>Tertib-i Risâle-i Ebrî</i>, which is dated based on internal evidence to after 1615. The instructions for several <i>ebru</i> techniques in the text are accredited to this master. Another famous 18th-century master by the name of Hatip Mehmed Efendi (died 1773) is accredited with developing motifs and perhaps early floral designs, although evidence from India appears to contradict some of these reports. Despite this, marbled motifs are commonly referred to as <i>hatip</i> designs in Turkey today.<sup id="cite_ref-turkishculture.org3_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-turkishculture.org3-398">[396]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature_and_theatre">Literature and theatre</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">Turkish literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_Turkey" title="Theatre of Turkey">Theatre of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kemalbey.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Kemalbey.jpg/170px-Kemalbey.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Kemalbey.jpg/255px-Kemalbey.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Kemalbey.jpg/340px-Kemalbey.jpg 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="589"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kemalbey.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Nam%C4%B1k_Kemal" title="Namık Kemal">Namık Kemal</a>'s works had a profound influence on <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">Atatürk</a> and other Turkish statesmen who established the Turkish Republic.<sup id="cite_ref-ÁgostonMasters2009-48_399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ÁgostonMasters2009-48-399">[397]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ShawShaw1977-260-261_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ShawShaw1977-260-261-400">[398]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Orhan_Pamuk.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Orhan_Pamuk.jpg/220px-Orhan_Pamuk.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="117" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Orhan_Pamuk.jpg/330px-Orhan_Pamuk.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Orhan_Pamuk.jpg/440px-Orhan_Pamuk.jpg 2x" data-file-width="521" data-file-height="276"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Orhan_Pamuk.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Orhan_Pamuk" title="Orhan Pamuk">Orhan Pamuk</a>, recipient of the 2006 <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a>, and his <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Angora" title="Turkish Angora">Turkish Angora cat</a> at his personal writing space in Istanbul.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">Turkish literature</a> is a mix of cultural influences. Interaction between the Ottoman Empire and the Islamic world along with Europe contributed to a blend of Turkic, Islamic and European traditions in modern-day Turkish music and literary arts.<sup id="cite_ref-ottomus_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ottomus-401">[399]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">Turkish literature</a> was heavily influenced by <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">Persian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arabic_literature" title="Arabic literature">Arabic literature</a> during most of the Ottoman era. The <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Tanzimat</a> reforms introduced previously unknown Western genres, primarily the novel and the short story. Many of the writers in the Tanzimat period wrote in several genres simultaneously: for instance, the poet <a href="/wiki/Namik_Kemal" class="mw-redirect" title="Namik Kemal">Nâmık Kemal</a> also wrote the important 1876 novel <i>İntibâh</i> (Awakening), while the journalist <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0brahim_%C5%9Einasi" title="İbrahim Şinasi">Şinasi</a> has written, in 1860, the first modern Turkish play, the <a href="/wiki/One_act_play" class="mw-redirect" title="One act play">one-act</a> comedy "<i>Şair Evlenmesi</i>" (The Poet's Marriage). Most of the roots of modern Turkish literature were formed between the years 1896 and 1923. Broadly, there were three primary literary movements during this period: the <i>Edebiyat-ı Cedîde</i> (New Literature) movement; the <i>Fecr-i Âtî</i> (Dawn of the Future) movement; and the <i>Millî Edebiyat</i> (National Literature) movement. The first radical step of innovation in 20th century Turkish poetry was taken by <a href="/wiki/N%C3%A2z%C4%B1m_Hikmet_Ran" class="mw-redirect" title="Nâzım Hikmet Ran">Nâzım Hikmet</a>, who introduced the <a href="/wiki/Free_verse" title="Free verse">free verse</a> style. Another revolution in Turkish poetry came about in 1941 with the <a href="/wiki/Garip" title="Garip">Garip</a> movement led by <a href="/wiki/Orhan_Veli_Kan%C4%B1k" title="Orhan Veli Kanık">Orhan Veli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oktay_R%C4%B1fat_Horozcu" title="Oktay Rıfat Horozcu">Oktay Rıfat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Melih_Cevdet_Anday" title="Melih Cevdet Anday">Melih Cevdet</a>. The mix of cultural influences in Turkey is dramatised, for example, in the form of the "new symbols of the clash and interlacing of cultures" enacted in the novels of <a href="/wiki/Orhan_Pamuk" title="Orhan Pamuk">Orhan Pamuk</a>, recipient of the 2006 <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[400]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The origin of <a href="/wiki/Turkish_theatre" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish theatre">Turkish theatre</a> dates back to ancient pagan rituals and oral legends. The dances, music and songs performed during the rituals of the inhabitants of Anatolia millennia ago are the elements from which the first shows originated. In time, the ancient rituals, myths, legends and stories evolved into theatrical shows. Starting from the 11th-century, the traditions of the Seljuk Turks blended with those of the indigenous peoples of Anatolia and the interaction between diverse cultures paved the way for new plays. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul,_Turkey.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg/220px-S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg/330px-S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg/440px-S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3951" data-file-height="2861"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul,_Turkey.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House" title="Süreyya Opera House">Süreyya Opera House</a> in Istanbul
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After the <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Tanzimat</a> (Reformation) period in the 19th century, characters in Turkish theatre were modernised and plays were performed on European-style stages, with actors wearing European costumes. Following the <a href="/wiki/Second_Constitutional_Era" title="Second Constitutional Era">restoration of constitutional monarchy</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Young_Turk_Revolution" title="Young Turk Revolution">Young Turk Revolution</a> in 1908, theatrical activities increased and social problems began to be reflected at the theatre as well as in historical plays. A theatrical conservatoire, <a href="/wiki/Dar%C3%BClbedayi" title="Darülbedayi">Darülbedayi-i Osmani</a> (which became the nucleus of the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_City_Theatres" title="Istanbul City Theatres">Istanbul City Theatres</a>) was established in 1914. During the years of chaos and war, the Darülbedayi-i Osmani continued its activities and attracted the younger generation. Numerous Turkish playwrights emerged in this era; some of them wrote on romantic subjects, while others were interested in social problems, and still others dealt with nationalistic themes. The first Turkish musicals were also written in this period. In time, Turkish women began to appear on stage, which was an important development in the late Ottoman society. Until then, female roles had only been played by actresses who were members of Turkey's ethnic minorities. Today there are numerous private theatres in the country, together with those which are subsidised by the government, such as the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_State_Theatres" title="Turkish State Theatres">Turkish State Theatres</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-turkishculture.org4_403-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-turkishculture.org4-403">[401]</a></sup> Notable players, directors and playwrights of Turkish theatre include <a href="/wiki/Muhsin_Ertu%C4%9Frul" title="Muhsin Ertuğrul">Muhsin Ertuğrul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haldun_Taner" title="Haldun Taner">Haldun Taner</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aziz_Nesin" title="Aziz Nesin">Aziz Nesin</a>, <a href="/wiki/G%C3%BClriz_Sururi" title="Gülriz Sururi">Gülriz Sururi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1z_Kenter" title="Yıldız Kenter">Yıldız Kenter</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C3%BC%C5%9Ffik_Kenter" title="Müşfik Kenter">Müşfik Kenter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haldun_Dormen" title="Haldun Dormen">Haldun Dormen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sadri_Al%C4%B1%C5%9F%C4%B1k" title="Sadri Alışık">Sadri Alışık</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%87olpan_%C4%B0lhan" title="Çolpan İlhan">Çolpan İlhan</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C3%BCnir_%C3%96zkul" title="Münir Özkul">Münir Özkul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adile_Na%C5%9Fit" title="Adile Naşit">Adile Naşit</a>, <a href="/wiki/Erol_G%C3%BCnayd%C4%B1n" title="Erol Günaydın">Erol Günaydın</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gazanfer_%C3%96zcan" title="Gazanfer Özcan">Gazanfer Özcan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nejat_Uygur" title="Nejat Uygur">Nejat Uygur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genco_Erkal" title="Genco Erkal">Genco Erkal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metin_Serezli" title="Metin Serezli">Metin Serezli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nevra_Serezli" title="Nevra Serezli">Nevra Serezli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Levent_K%C4%B1rca" title="Levent Kırca">Levent Kırca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zeki_Alasya" title="Zeki Alasya">Zeki Alasya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metin_Akp%C4%B1nar" title="Metin Akpınar">Metin Akpınar</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C3%BCjdat_Gezen" title="Müjdat Gezen">Müjdat Gezen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ferhan_%C5%9Eensoy" title="Ferhan Şensoy">Ferhan Şensoy</a>, among others. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music_and_dance">Music and dance</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_dance" title="Turkish dance">Turkish dance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Turkey" title="Music of Turkey">Music of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_classical_music" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish classical music">Turkish classical music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_folk_music" title="Turkish folk music">Turkish folk music</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_music_(style)" title="Turkish music (style)">Turkish music (style)</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg/220px-Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="246" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg/330px-Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg/440px-Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="658" data-file-height="736"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Referred to as <i>Süperstar</i> by the Turkish media, <a href="/wiki/Ajda_Pekkan" title="Ajda Pekkan">Ajda Pekkan</a> is a prominent figure of <a href="/wiki/Turkish_pop_music" title="Turkish pop music">Turkish pop music</a>, with a career spanning decades and a repertoire of diverse musical styles.<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[402]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Music_of_Turkey" title="Music of Turkey">Music of Turkey</a> includes mainly <a href="/wiki/Turkic_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkic culture">Turkic</a> elements as well as partial influences ranging from <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Central_Asia" title="Music of Central Asia">Central Asian folk music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabic_music" title="Arabic music">Arabic music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_music" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek music">Greek music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_music" title="Ottoman music">Ottoman music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_traditional_music" title="Persian traditional music">Persian music</a> and <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Southeastern_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Music of Southeastern Europe">Balkan music</a>, as well as references to more modern European and <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States" title="Music of the United States">American</a> <a href="/wiki/Popular_music" title="Popular music">popular music</a>. The roots of traditional music in Turkey span across centuries to a time when the <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Turks" class="mw-redirect" title="Seljuk Turks">Seljuk Turks</a> migrated to <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persia" class="mw-redirect" title="Persia">Persia</a> in the 11th century and contains elements of both Turkic and pre-Turkic influences. Much of its modern popular music can trace its roots to the emergence in the early 1930s drive for <a href="/wiki/Westernization" title="Westernization">Westernization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-soundsofanatolia_405-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-soundsofanatolia-405">[403]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>With the assimilation of immigrants from various regions the diversity of musical genres and musical instrumentation also expanded. Turkey has also seen documented folk music and recorded popular music produced in the ethnic styles of <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Greece" title="Music of Greece">Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Armenia" title="Music of Armenia">Armenian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Albania" title="Music of Albania">Albanian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Poland" title="Music of Poland">Polish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jewish" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewish">Jewish</a> communities, among others.<sup id="cite_ref-lesartsturcs_406-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lesartsturcs-406">[404]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Many Turkish cities and towns have vibrant local music scenes which, in turn, support a number of regional musical styles. Despite this however, western music styles like <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">pop music</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kanto_(music)" title="Kanto (music)">kanto</a> lost popularity to <a href="/wiki/Arabesque" title="Arabesque">arabesque</a> in the late 1970s and 1980s. It became popular again by the beginning of the 1990s, as a result of an opening economy and society. With the support of <a href="/wiki/Sezen_Aksu" title="Sezen Aksu">Sezen Aksu</a>, the resurging popularity of pop music gave rise to several international Turkish pop stars such as <a href="/wiki/Ajda_Pekkan" title="Ajda Pekkan">Ajda Pekkan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tarkan_(singer)" title="Tarkan (singer)">Tarkan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sertab_Erener" title="Sertab Erener">Sertab Erener</a>. The late 1990s also saw an emergence of underground music producing alternative <a href="/wiki/Turkish_rock_music" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish rock music">Turkish rock</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electronica" title="Electronica">electronica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_hip_hop" title="Turkish hip hop">hip-hop</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">rap</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dance_music" title="Dance music">dance music</a> in opposition to the mainstream corporate <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">pop</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arabesque_music" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabesque music">arabesque</a> genres, which many believe have become too commercial.<sup id="cite_ref-musicscene_407-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-musicscene-407">[405]</a></sup> Internationally acclaimed Turkish <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Blues" title="Blues">blues</a> musicians and composers include <a href="/wiki/Ahmet_Ertegun" title="Ahmet Ertegun">Ahmet Ertegun</a> (founder and president of <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Records" title="Atlantic Records">Atlantic Records</a>), <a href="/wiki/N%C3%BCkhet_Ruacan" title="Nükhet Ruacan">Nükhet Ruacan</a> and Kerem Görsev. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Baris_Manco.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Baris_Manco.jpg/220px-Baris_Manco.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="129" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Baris_Manco.jpg/330px-Baris_Manco.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Baris_Manco.jpg/440px-Baris_Manco.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1272" data-file-height="745"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Baris_Manco.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bar%C4%B1%C5%9F_Man%C3%A7o" title="Barış Manço">Barış Manço</a> was a Turkish rock musician and one of the founders of the <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_rock" title="Anatolian rock">Anatolian rock</a> genre.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Five" title="Turkish Five">Turkish Five</a> is a name used by some authors to identify the five pioneers of Western classical music in Turkey, namely <a href="/wiki/Ahmed_Adnan_Saygun" class="mw-redirect" title="Ahmed Adnan Saygun">Ahmed Adnan Saygun</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ulvi_Cemal_Erkin" title="Ulvi Cemal Erkin">Ulvi Cemal Erkin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cemal_Re%C5%9Fit_Rey" title="Cemal Reşit Rey">Cemal Reşit Rey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hasan_Ferit_Alnar" title="Hasan Ferit Alnar">Hasan Ferit Alnar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Necil_Kaz%C4%B1m_Akses" title="Necil Kazım Akses">Necil Kazım Akses</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-İlyasoğlu_408-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-İlyasoğlu-408">[406]</a></sup> Internationally acclaimed Turkish musicians of Western classical music include pianists <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0dil_Biret" title="İdil Biret">İdil Biret</a>, <a href="/wiki/Verda_Erman" title="Verda Erman">Verda Erman</a>, <a href="/wiki/G%C3%BClsin_Onay" title="Gülsin Onay">Gülsin Onay</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pekinel_sisters" title="Pekinel sisters">Pekinel sisters</a> (Güher and Süher Pekinel), <a href="/wiki/Ay%C5%9Feg%C3%BCl_Sar%C4%B1ca" title="Ayşegül Sarıca">Ayşegül Sarıca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Faz%C4%B1l_Say" title="Fazıl Say">Fazıl Say</a>; violinists <a href="/wiki/Ayla_Erduran" title="Ayla Erduran">Ayla Erduran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Suna_Kan" title="Suna Kan">Suna Kan</a>; opera singers <a href="/wiki/Semiha_Berksoy" title="Semiha Berksoy">Semiha Berksoy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leyla_Gencer" title="Leyla Gencer">Leyla Gencer</a> and <a href="/wiki/G%C3%BCne%C5%9F_G%C3%BCrle" title="Güneş Gürle">Güneş Gürle</a>; and conductors <a href="/wiki/Emre_Arac%C4%B1" title="Emre Aracı">Emre Aracı</a>, <a href="/wiki/G%C3%BCrer_Aykal" title="Gürer Aykal">Gürer Aykal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Erol_Erdin%C3%A7" title="Erol Erdinç">Erol Erdinç</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rengim_G%C3%B6kmen" title="Rengim Gökmen">Rengim Gökmen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hikmet_%C5%9Eim%C5%9Fek" title="Hikmet Şimşek">Hikmet Şimşek</a>. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Turkish_dance" title="Turkish dance">Turkish folk dance</a> is diverse. <i><a href="/wiki/Hora_(dance)" title="Hora (dance)">Hora</a></i> is performed in <a href="/wiki/East_Thrace" title="East Thrace">East Thrace</a>; <i><a href="/wiki/Zeybek_dance" title="Zeybek dance">Zeybek</a></i> in the <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Region" title="Aegean Region">Aegean Region</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marmara_Region" title="Marmara Region">Southern Marmara</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" title="Central Anatolia Region">East-Central Anatolia Region</a>; <i>Teke</i> in the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean Region">Western Mediterranean Region</a>; <i>Kaşık Oyunları</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Kar%C5%9F%C4%B1lama" class="mw-redirect" title="Karşılama">Karşılama</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" title="Central Anatolia Region">West-Central Anatolia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region" title="Black Sea Region">Western Black Sea Region</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marmara_Region" title="Marmara Region">Southern Marmara Region</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean Region">Eastern Mediterranean Region</a>; <i><a href="/wiki/Horon" class="mw-redirect" title="Horon">Horon</a></i> in the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region" title="Black Sea Region">Central and Eastern Black Sea Region</a>; <i><a href="/wiki/Halay" title="Halay">Halay</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Eastern Anatolia Region">Eastern Anatolia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" title="Central Anatolia Region">Central Anatolia Region</a>; and <i><a href="/wiki/Bar_(dance)" title="Bar (dance)">Bar</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Lezginka" title="Lezginka">Lezginka</a></i> in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Eastern Anatolia Region">Northeastern Anatolia Region</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-.ncturkishfestival._409-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-.ncturkishfestival.-409">[407]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Turkey" title="Architecture of Turkey">Architecture of Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_architecture" title="Seljuk architecture">Seljuk architecture</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">Ottoman architecture</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG/200px-%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG/300px-%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG/400px-%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2304"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG/200px-Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="154" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG/300px-Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG/400px-Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2417" data-file-height="1865"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Main_Post_Office" class="mw-redirect" title="Istanbul Main Post Office">Grand Post Office</a> (1905–1909) in Istanbul and the first <a href="/wiki/Ziraat_Bank" title="Ziraat Bank">Ziraat Bank</a> headquarters (1925–1929) in Ankara are among the examples of <a href="/wiki/First_National_Architectural_Movement" class="mw-redirect" title="First National Architectural Movement">Turkish Neoclassical architecture</a> in the early 20th century.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Byzantine era is usually dated from 330 AD, when Constantine the Great moved the Roman capital to Byzantium, which became Constantinople, until the fall of the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a> in 1453. Its architecture dramatically influenced the later medieval architecture throughout Europe and the Near East, and became the primary progenitor of the Renaissance and Ottoman architectural traditions that followed its collapse. When the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> went Christian (as well as Eastwards) with its new capital at <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>, its architecture became more sensuous and more ambitious. This new style would come to be known as Byzantine with increasingly exotic domes and ever-richer mosaics, traveled west to Ravenna and Venice and as far north as Moscow. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_architecture" title="Seljuk architecture">architecture of the Seljuk Turks</a> combined the elements and characteristics of the <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Central_Asia" title="Architecture of Central Asia">Turkic architecture of Central Asia</a> with those of <a href="/wiki/Persian_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Persian architecture">Persian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab architecture">Arab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenian_architecture" title="Armenian architecture">Armenian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine</a> architecture. The transition from Seljuk architecture to <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">Ottoman architecture</a> is most visible in <a href="/wiki/Bursa" title="Bursa">Bursa</a>, which was the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman State</a> between 1335 and 1413. Following the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">Ottoman conquest of Constantinople (Istanbul)</a> in 1453, Ottoman architecture was significantly influenced by <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine architecture</a>. <a href="/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace" title="Topkapı Palace">Topkapı Palace</a> in Istanbul is one of the most famous examples of classical Ottoman architecture and was the primary residence of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Sultan" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman Sultan">Ottoman Sultans</a> for approximately 400 years.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-410">[408]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Sinan" title="Mimar Sinan">Mimar Sinan</a> (c.1489–1588) was the most important architect of the classical period in Ottoman architecture. He was the chief architect of at least 374 buildings which were constructed in various <a href="/wiki/Eyalet" title="Eyalet">provinces</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> in the 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[409]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since the 18th century, Turkish architecture has been increasingly influenced by European styles, and this can be particularly seen in the <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Tanzimat</a> era buildings of Istanbul like the <a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="Dolmabahçe Palace">Dolmabahçe</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%87%C4%B1ra%C4%9Fan_Palace" title="Çırağan Palace">Çırağan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Feriye_Saraylar%C4%B1" class="mw-redirect" title="Feriye Sarayları">Feriye</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beylerbeyi_Palace" title="Beylerbeyi Palace">Beylerbeyi</a>, <a href="/wiki/K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCksu_Palace" class="mw-redirect" title="Küçüksu Palace">Küçüksu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ihlamur_Palace" class="mw-redirect" title="Ihlamur Palace">Ihlamur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1z_Palace" title="Yıldız Palace">Yıldız</a> <a href="/wiki/Palace" title="Palace">palaces</a>, which were all designed by members of the <a href="/wiki/Balyan_family" title="Balyan family">Balyan family</a> of Ottoman Armenian court architects.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[410]</a></sup> The Ottoman era <a href="/wiki/Yal%C4%B1" title="Yalı">waterfront houses (<i>yalı</i>)</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus" class="mw-redirect" title="Bosphorus">Bosphorus</a> also reflect the fusion between classical Ottoman and European architectural styles during the aforementioned period. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/First_National_Architectural_Movement" class="mw-redirect" title="First National Architectural Movement">First National Architectural Movement</a> in the early 20th century sought to create a new architecture, which was based on motifs from Seljuk and Ottoman architecture. The leading architects of this movement were <a href="/wiki/Vedat_Tek" title="Vedat Tek">Vedat Tek</a> (1873–1942), <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Kemaleddin_Bey" class="mw-redirect" title="Mimar Kemaleddin Bey">Mimar Kemaleddin Bey</a> (1870–1927), <a href="/wiki/Arif_Hikmet_Koyuno%C4%9Flu" title="Arif Hikmet Koyunoğlu">Arif Hikmet Koyunoğlu</a> (1888–1982) and Giulio Mongeri (1873–1953).<sup id="cite_ref-turkisharch_413-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-turkisharch-413">[411]</a></sup> Buildings from this era are the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Main_Post_Office" class="mw-redirect" title="Istanbul Main Post Office">Grand Post Office</a> in Istanbul (1905–1909), <a href="/wiki/Tayyare_Apartments" title="Tayyare Apartments">Tayyare Apartments</a> (1919–1922),<sup id="cite_ref-tayyare_414-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tayyare-414">[412]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_4th_Vak%C4%B1f_Han" title="Istanbul 4th Vakıf Han">Istanbul 4th Vakıf Han</a> (1911–1926),<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[413]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/State_Art_and_Sculpture_Museum" title="State Art and Sculpture Museum">State Art and Sculpture Museum</a> (1927–1930),<sup id="cite_ref-stateart_416-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stateart-416">[414]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ethnography_Museum_of_Ankara" title="Ethnography Museum of Ankara">Ethnography Museum of Ankara</a> (1925–1928),<sup id="cite_ref-Ethnography_417-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnography-417">[415]</a></sup> the first <a href="/wiki/Ziraat_Bank" title="Ziraat Bank">Ziraat Bank</a> headquarters in Ankara (1925–1929),<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[416]</a></sup> the first <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrkiye_%C4%B0%C5%9F_Bankas%C4%B1" class="mw-redirect" title="Türkiye İş Bankası">Türkiye İş Bankası</a> headquarters in Ankara (1926–1929),<sup id="cite_ref-işbank_419-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-işbank-419">[417]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bebek,_Istanbul" class="mw-redirect" title="Bebek, Istanbul">Bebek</a> Mosque,<sup id="cite_ref-bebek_420-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bebek-420">[418]</a></sup> and Kamer Hatun Mosque.<sup id="cite_ref-kamer_421-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kamer-421">[419]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mass_422-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mass-422">[420]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">Turkish cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine" title="Ottoman cuisine">Ottoman cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/170px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="116" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/255px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/340px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2510" data-file-height="1719"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Turkish_coffee" title="Turkish coffee">Turkish coffee</a> with <a href="/wiki/Turkish_delight" title="Turkish delight">Turkish delight</a>. Turkish coffee is a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">UNESCO-listed intangible cultural heritage</a> of <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[421]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[422]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">Turkish cuisine</a> is largely the heritage of <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine" title="Ottoman cuisine">Ottoman cuisine</a>. In the early years of the Republic, a few studies were published about regional Anatolian dishes but cuisine did not feature heavily in Turkish folkloric studies until the 1980s, when the fledgling tourism industry encouraged the Turkish state to sponsor two food symposia. The papers submitted at the symposia presented the history of Turkish cuisine on a "historical continuum" that dated back to Turkic origins in Central Asia and continued through the Seljuk and Ottoman periods.<sup id="cite_ref-berg_425-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-berg-425">[423]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Many of the papers presented at these first two symposia were unreferenced. Prior to the symposia, the study of Turkish culinary culture was first popularised by the publication of Süheyl Ünver's <i>Fifty Dishes in Turkish History</i> in 1948. This book was based on recipes found in an 18th century Ottoman manuscript. His second book was about palace cuisine during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Mehmet_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Mehmet II">Mehmet II</a>. Following the publication of Ünver's book subsequent studies were published, including a 1978 study by a historian named Bahaettin Ögel about the <a href="/wiki/Central_Asian_cuisine" title="Central Asian cuisine">Central Asian</a> origins of Turkish cuisine.<sup id="cite_ref-berg_425-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-berg-425">[423]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine" title="Ottoman cuisine">Ottoman cuisine</a> contains elements of <a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">Turkish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_cuisine" title="Byzantine cuisine">Byzantine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balkan_cuisine" title="Balkan cuisine">Balkan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenian_cuisine" title="Armenian cuisine">Armenian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_cuisine" title="Kurdish cuisine">Kurdish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_cuisine" title="Arab cuisine">Arab</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persian_cuisine" class="mw-redirect" title="Persian cuisine">Persian</a> cuisines.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[424]</a></sup> The country's position between Europe, Asia, and the Mediterranean Sea helped the Turks in gaining complete control of the major <a href="/wiki/Trade_route" title="Trade route">trade routes</a>, and an ideal landscape and climate allowed plants and animals to flourish. Turkish cuisine was well established by the mid-1400s, the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>'s six hundred-year reign. <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">Yogurt</a> salads, fish in <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">olive oil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sharbat" title="Sharbat">sherbet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dolma" title="Dolma">stuffed and wrapped vegetables</a> became Turkish staples. The empire, eventually spanning from <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">Austria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> to <a href="/wiki/Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabia">Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a>, used its land and water routes to import exotic ingredients from all over the world. By the end of the 16th century, the Ottoman court housed over 1,400 live-in cooks and passed laws regulating the freshness of food. Since the fall of the empire in World War I (1914–1918) and the establishment of the Turkish Republic in 1923, foreign food such as French hollandaise sauce and Western fast food have made their way into the modern Turkish diet.<sup id="cite_ref-foodbycountry.com_427-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foodbycountry.com-427">[425]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Sports in Turkey">Sports in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Turkey" title="Football in Turkey">Football in Turkey</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg/220px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg/330px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg/440px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
